fields.title: February 1664
fields.text:
Talk of the growing tension between the English and the Dutch circulates ([2](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/02/02/), [9](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/02/09/)) with the Dutch proclaiming that they are the "Soveraigne of all the South Seas" ([15](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/02/15/)). Business concerns include issues regarding the quality of masts ([16](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/02/16/), [17](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/02/17/), [18](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/02/18/), [21](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/02/21/), [22](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/02/22/)); a letter on the behalf of Mr. Barrow ([16](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/02/16/)); Mr. Maes' customs issue ([4](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/02/04/), [10](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/02/10/)); hempe and trade ([24](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/02/24/)); Creed and his pieces of eight ([4](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/02/04/), [10](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/02/10/)); a review of Lord Peterborough's accounts ([13](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/02/13/), [18](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/02/18/), [25](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/02/25/), [26](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/02/26/), [27](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/02/27/)) and a detailed report on the state of  England's Revenues by Sir Phillip Warwick, which totally captivates Sam ([29](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/02/29/)).  Sam benefits from his position through a gifts from Sir W. Warren ([2](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/02/02/)),   Mr. Falconer ([11](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/02/11/)), and  Mrs. Russell.  

Elizabeth brings news that Balty and his wife will leave for his soldier duty in Holland ([3](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/02/03/)). Uncle Wright's "caresses" and private visits to Elizabeth leave Sam to believe that "it looks strange putting all together, but yet I am in hopes he means well" ([19](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/02/19/), [22](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/02/22/), [26](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/02/26/)).  The concerns that Sam had early in the month that he may have gotten Mrs. Lane pregnant ([1](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/02/01/)) were not put at ease when the marriage that he was hoping to arrange between her and Hawley seems to fall apart ([8](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/02/08/)). Sam vows that he is now "resolved wholly to avoid occasion of further ill with her" ([29](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/02/29/)). His receives advice from Mr. Howe regarding his relationship with Lord Sandwich ([3](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/02/03/), [8](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/02/08/)). Howe "did of himself advise me to appear more free with my Lord and to come to him, for my own strangeness he tells me he thinks do make my Lord the worse." ([29](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/02/29/))

Court gossip includes the Duke's new perriwigg ([15](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/02/15/)), Lady Castlemaine's theater antics ([1](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/02/01/)), the scathing condition of foreign policy, pathetic internal court politics, and a deep concern for the overall welfare of England under King Charles II ([22](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/02/22/)). On a more playful note, Sam enjoys seeing "The Indian Queene" with Elizabeth ([1](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/02/01/)), buying two books ([22](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/02/22/)), observing sand, louse and mites under a microscope ([13](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/02/13/)), watching marble being cut ([24](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/02/24/)) and receiving a new mastiffe named "Towser" ([17](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/02/17/)) who he thinks he will give to his father as a present ([18](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/02/18/)).
fields.text_html:
Talk of the growing tension between the English and the Dutch circulates (2, 9) with the Dutch proclaiming that they are the "Soveraigne of all the South Seas" (15). Business concerns include issues regarding the quality of masts (16, 17, 18, 21, 22); a letter on the behalf of Mr. Barrow (16); Mr. Maes' customs issue (4, 10); hempe and trade (24); Creed and his pieces of eight (4, 10); a review of Lord Peterborough's accounts (13, 18, 25, 26, 27) and a detailed report on the state of England's Revenues by Sir Phillip Warwick, which totally captivates Sam (29). Sam benefits from his position through a gifts from Sir W. Warren (2), Mr. Falconer (11), and Mrs. Russell.

Elizabeth brings news that Balty and his wife will leave for his soldier duty in Holland (3). Uncle Wright's "caresses" and private visits to Elizabeth leave Sam to believe that "it looks strange putting all together, but yet I am in hopes he means well" (19, 22, 26). The concerns that Sam had early in the month that he may have gotten Mrs. Lane pregnant (1) were not put at ease when the marriage that he was hoping to arrange between her and Hawley seems to fall apart (8). Sam vows that he is now "resolved wholly to avoid occasion of further ill with her" (29). His receives advice from Mr. Howe regarding his relationship with Lord Sandwich (3, 8). Howe "did of himself advise me to appear more free with my Lord and to come to him, for my own strangeness he tells me he thinks do make my Lord the worse." (29)

Court gossip includes the Duke's new perriwigg (15), Lady Castlemaine's theater antics (1), the scathing condition of foreign policy, pathetic internal court politics, and a deep concern for the overall welfare of England under King Charles II (22). On a more playful note, Sam enjoys seeing "The Indian Queene" with Elizabeth (1), buying two books (22), observing sand, louse and mites under a microscope (13), watching marble being cut (24) and receiving a new mastiffe named "Towser" (17) who he thinks he will give to his father as a present (18).

fields.title: March 1664
fields.text:
March begins on an upbeat note as Lord Sandwich praises Sam to Lord Peterborough and Povy ([3](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/03/03/)). Lord Sandwich's favour also yields Sam's a role as an assistant under the Duke of York in the newly created Corporation of the Royal Fishery ([10](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/03/10/)). Sam celebrates the new month by bending his vows to see two plays, "The Unfortunate Lovers" and "Heraclius" ([7](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/03/07/), [8](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/03/08/)). 

Happiness is short lived when Tom takes a turn for the worse. When Mrs. Turner's son arrives with a note that Tom's illness may be the pox ([13](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/03/13/)), Sam is rightly upset regarding such shameful accusations. Sam visits Tom several times over the following days as his health deteriorates. Sam assists as two different doctors check Tom's body for signs of the pox, but there are none, which offer Sam some relief ([15](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/03/15/)).  Meanwhile Sam starts to gather details regarding the nature of Tom's lifestyle, including his debts, mysterious meetings with Cave and Cranburne, and his bad husbandry ([13](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/03/13/), [14](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/03/14/)). Tom passes away, and amidst funeral preparations, Sam discovers among Tom's papers some back-stabbing letters written about him by his brother John ([15](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/03/15/)). Sam's father arrives a "poor man, very sad and sickly," and has barely a moment to grieve before an angry Sam confronts him about the content of John's letters ([16](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/03/16/), [18](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/03/18/), [19](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/03/19/), [21](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/03/21/)). As the days progress, Sam seeks advice from Mr. Moore regarding who should administer Tom's estate ([27](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/03/27/)).

Among the despair, a hilarious lightness is found when Sam decides that Mrs. Buggin's decidedly beautiful dog should mate with his bitch and he helps him along ([23](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/03/23/), [24](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/03/24/)). The month ends at Sam's house with a happy dinner gathering as Sam celebrates his "solemn feast" for the cutting of his stone ([26](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/03/26/)).

Happiness is short lived when Tom takes a turn for the worse. When Mrs. Turner's son arrives with a note that Tom's illness may be the pox (13), Sam is rightly upset regarding such shameful accusations. Sam visits Tom several times over the following days as his health deteriorates. Sam assists as two different doctors check Tom's body for signs of the pox, but there are none, which offer Sam some relief (15). Meanwhile Sam starts to gather details regarding the nature of Tom's lifestyle, including his debts, mysterious meetings with Cave and Cranburne, and his bad husbandry (13, 14). Tom passes away, and amidst funeral preparations, Sam discovers among Tom's papers some back-stabbing letters written about him by his brother John (15). Sam's father arrives a "poor man, very sad and sickly," and has barely a moment to grieve before an angry Sam confronts him about the content of John's letters (16, 18, 19, 21). As the days progress, Sam seeks advice from Mr. Moore regarding who should administer Tom's estate (27).

Among the despair, a hilarious lightness is found when Sam decides that Mrs. Buggin's decidedly beautiful dog should mate with his bitch and he helps him along (23, 24). The month ends at Sam's house with a happy dinner gathering as Sam celebrates his "solemn feast" for the cutting of his stone (26).

fields.title: April 1664
fields.text: April brings continued efforts to settle brother Tom's estate ([16](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/04/16/)) and the shocking surprise that Tom had fathered a daughter with his maid Margaret ([6](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/04/06/)). Concerns over a potential Dutch war overwhelm many of Sam's conversations ([4](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/04/04/), [13](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/04/13/), [20](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/04/20/), [23](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/04/23/)). While Howe and others plot for a favored spot should war begin ([12](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/04/12/)), Sam's fears for the safety of his accounts, which could be lost, should Lord Sandwich perish in battle ([23](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/04/23/), [25](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/04/25/), [26](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/04/26/)). The month ends with a more impending concern over loss of life when Lady Sandwich, Sam's favourite, becomes ill with either the measles or, as Sam fears, perhaps smallpox ([29](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/04/29/), [30](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/04/30/)).
fields.text_html: April brings continued efforts to settle brother Tom's estate (16) and the shocking surprise that Tom had fathered a daughter with his maid Margaret (6). Concerns over a potential Dutch war overwhelm many of Sam's conversations (4, 13, 20, 23). While Howe and others plot for a favored spot should war begin (12), Sam's fears for the safety of his accounts, which could be lost, should Lord Sandwich perish in battle (23, 25, 26). The month ends with a more impending concern over loss of life when Lady Sandwich, Sam's favourite, becomes ill with either the measles or, as Sam fears, perhaps smallpox (29, 30).

fields.title: May 1664
fields.text: Navy work includes Sam's ongoing disgust with Sir W. Batten ([3](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/05/03/), [5](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/05/05/), [22](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/05/22/), [26](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/05/26/)); discussions of the possibility of a Dutch War with Coventry ([12](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/05/12/), [18](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/05/18/), [21](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/05/21/), [22](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/05/22/), [29](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/05/29/)); his bribe from Captain Taylor ([27](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/05/27/)); his interest in shipbuilding ([7](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/05/07/), [13](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/05/13/), [30](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/05/30/)); and his unusual role as a go-between to elicit Lord Sandwich (at Coventry's request) to see if he would go to sea under the Duke of York should war with the Dutch prevail ([29](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/05/29/),31). In personal matters Sam is relieved to find Lady Sandwich on the mend ([9](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/05/09/), [12](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/05/12/)) and thrilled that work on his closet was done so well ([6](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/05/06/)). On the more worrisome side, he notes the death of Uncle Fenner ([24](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/05/24/)), his offer to take Pall into his house to find her a husband ([17](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/05/17/), [20](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/05/20/)), his discussions about Tom's estate and condolences to his Cozen Scott at the loss of his wife ( [4](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/05/04/)) along with his illness ([14](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/05/14/), [15](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/05/15/), [17](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/05/17/), [19](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/05/19/), [31](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/05/31/)). Uncle Wight reveals his true intentions as he expresses his desire to father a child with Elizabeth along with the bribe of "500l. money or jewels beforehand, and make[ing] the child his heir", thus leaving a most disturbed Sam to realize that "all of his kindness is but lust of her" ([11](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/05/11/)).
fields.text_html:
Navy work includes Sam's ongoing disgust with Sir W. Batten (3, 5, 22, 26); discussions of the possibility of a Dutch War with Coventry (12, 18, 21, 22, 29); his bribe from Captain Taylor (27); his interest in shipbuilding (7, 13, 30); and his unusual role as a go-between to elicit Lord Sandwich (at Coventry's request) to see if he would go to sea under the Duke of York should war with the Dutch prevail (29,31).

In personal matters Sam is relieved to find Lady Sandwich on the mend (9, 12) and thrilled that work on his closet was done so well (6). On the more worrisome side, he notes the death of Uncle Fenner (24), his offer to take Pall into his house to find her a husband (17, 20), his discussions about Tom's estate and condolences to his Cozen Scott at the loss of his wife ( 4) along with his illness (14, 15, 17, 19, 31). Uncle Wight reveals his true intentions as he expresses his desire to father a child with Elizabeth along with the bribe of "500l. money or jewels beforehand, and make[ing] the child his heir", thus leaving a most disturbed Sam to realize that "all of his kindness is but lust of her" (11).

fields.title: June 1664
fields.text:
Tangiers is in the forefront with news of Lord Teviot's death ([1](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/06/01/), [15](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/06/15/)); poorly run committee meetings ([3](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/06/03/), [4](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/06/04/), [10](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/06/10/), [13](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/06/13/)); Sam's efforts to secure and provision the ships ([16](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/06/16/), [24](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/06/24/)) and a potential payout from Captain Taylor ([3](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/06/03/)). 

Concerns surround Lord Sandwich as Pepys and Lady Sandwich worry about his debts ([23](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/06/23/), [29](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/06/29/)). Sam moves to ensure the security of the Wardrobe position once promised to his father ([4](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/06/04/), [20](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/06/20/)). Sam (and possibly Lady Sandwich) meet Mrs. Becke, the rumored mistress of Lord Sandwich ([14](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/06/14/), [20](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/06/20/)).

Mr. Coventry gives Sam an interesting discourse on active and passive valour ([4](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/06/04/)) while Mr. Pierce provides contrasts of another sort when he gives Sam a tour of the Queen's bedchamber and closet and the King's closet ([24](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/06/24/)).
fields.text_html:
Tangiers is in the forefront with news of Lord Teviot's death (1, 15); poorly run committee meetings (3, 4, 10, 13); Sam's efforts to secure and provision the ships (16, 24) and a potential payout from Captain Taylor (3).

Concerns surround Lord Sandwich as Pepys and Lady Sandwich worry about his debts (23, 29). Sam moves to ensure the security of the Wardrobe position once promised to his father (4, 20). Sam (and possibly Lady Sandwich) meet Mrs. Becke, the rumored mistress of Lord Sandwich (14, 20).

Mr. Coventry gives Sam an interesting discourse on active and passive valour (4) while Mr. Pierce provides contrasts of another sort when he gives Sam a tour of the Queen's bedchamber and closet and the King's closet (24).

fields.title: July 1664
fields.text: Sam argues with Elizabeth about a pair of earring she has bought ([4](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/07/04/)). The couple reconciles and visits Lord Sandwich aboard the Hope ([4](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/07/04/)) prior to Elizabeth's departure to the country ([9](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/07/09/), [10](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/07/10/), [11](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/07/11/)). Lord Sandwich shares details of his estate with Sam ([15](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/07/15/)) and warns him of a situation where Sam has inadvertently angered the Lord Chancellor ([14](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/07/14/), [15](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/07/15/), [16](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/07/16/)). Sam tries to resolve the conflict of the cutting of the timber from Clarendon Parke with the help of Sir George Carteret ([18](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/07/18/)), but by month end, Mr. Coventry has placed Sam in a position of divided loyalty on this issue ([23](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/07/23/)). Sam records two lists including Dr. Burnett's health advice ([1](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/07/01/)) and input about how to have children ([26](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/07/26/)). Sam learns of Mrs. Lane's marriage ([21](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/07/21/)), but later meets her for a pleasurable tryst ([23](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/07/23/)). Sam is sworn in for the Committee for Fishing ([7](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/07/07/), [9](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/07/09/)) and works with Warren on a contract for 1,000 Gottenburg masts ([21](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/07/21/)). By month end he finds himself joyfully over the 1,000l. level and has splurged on seeing two plays, including "Worse and Worse" and "The Bondman".
fields.text_html:
Sam argues with Elizabeth about a pair of earring she has bought (4). The couple reconciles and visits Lord Sandwich aboard the Hope (4) prior to Elizabeth's departure to the country (9, 10, 11). Lord Sandwich shares details of his estate with Sam (15) and warns him of a situation where Sam has inadvertently angered the Lord Chancellor (14, 15, 16). Sam tries to resolve the conflict of the cutting of the timber from Clarendon Parke with the help of Sir George Carteret (18), but by month end, Mr. Coventry has placed Sam in a position of divided loyalty on this issue (23).

Sam records two lists including Dr. Burnett's health advice (1) and input about how to have children (26). Sam learns of Mrs. Lane's marriage (21), but later meets her for a pleasurable tryst (23). Sam is sworn in for the Committee for Fishing (7, 9) and works with Warren on a contract for 1,000 Gottenburg masts (21). By month end he finds himself joyfully over the 1,000l. level and has splurged on seeing two plays, including "Worse and Worse" and "The Bondman".

fields.title: August 1664
fields.text:
Sam decides to secure a female companion for Elizabeth ([1](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/08/01/), [15](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/08/15/), [23](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/08/23/)) and a boy for himself. By month end Tom Edwards is clothed for the job ([24](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/08/24/), [27](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/08/27/)) and Will has brought forth a strong candidate for Elizabeth ([29](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/08/29/)). Sam designates a room in his home for his "musique room' and the transformation works begins. Elizabeth's return home ([7](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/08/07/)) does not curb Sam's appetite for a tryst with Mrs. Lane ([15](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/08/15/)) who is now pregnant and finds her husband in need of a job. Troubles still brew with Tom's illegitimate child ([25](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/08/25/)).

Sam's health remains a concern with his bothersome cold legs causing him to have a special coat made for indoors ([1](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/08/01/), [13](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/08/13/), [14](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/08/14/)). Batten supplies Sam with Epsum water which helps him with his ongoing bowels issues ([17](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/08/17/), [21](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/08/21/)). Sam has a case made for his stone, costing him 24_s._, a large expense for such an item, but a precious reminder of surviving his dangerous operation ([19](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/08/19/), [27](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/08/27/)).

Sam rationalises his vow against plays ([8](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/08/08/)). Between himself and Elizabeth they see: "Bartholomew's Fayre" ([2](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/08/02/)), "The Rivall Ladys" ([4](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/08/04/)), "Flora's Figary" ([8](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/08/08/)), "Henry the Fifth" ([8](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/08/08/)) and "The Court Secret" ([18](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/08/18/)). Sam enjoys seeing paintings of the Queen and Frances Stewart ([26](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/08/26/)). For his scientific interests he has his slide rule engraved ([10](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/08/10/), [13](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/08/13/)) and buys a microscope and a scotoscope ([13](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/08/13/)).
fields.text_html:
Sam decides to secure a female companion for Elizabeth (1, 15, 23) and a boy for himself. By month end Tom Edwards is clothed for the job (24, 27) and Will has brought forth a strong candidate for Elizabeth (29). Sam designates a room in his home for his "musique room' and the transformation works begins. Elizabeth's return home (7) does not curb Sam's appetite for a tryst with Mrs. Lane (15) who is now pregnant and finds her husband in need of a job. Troubles still brew with Tom's illegitimate child (25).

Sam's health remains a concern with his bothersome cold legs causing him to have a special coat made for indoors (1, 13, 14). Batten supplies Sam with Epsum water which helps him with his ongoing bowels issues (17, 21). Sam has a case made for his stone, costing him 24_s._, a large expense for such an item, but a precious reminder of surviving his dangerous operation (19, 27).

Sam rationalises his vow against plays (8). Between himself and Elizabeth they see: "Bartholomew's Fayre" (2), "The Rivall Ladys" (4), "Flora's Figary" (8), "Henry the Fifth" (8) and "The Court Secret" (18). Sam enjoys seeing paintings of the Queen and Frances Stewart (26). For his scientific interests he has his slide rule engraved (10, 13) and buys a microscope and a scotoscope (13).

fields.title: September 1664
fields.text: The recent arrival of Mary Mercer, Elizabeth's new gentlewoman, and Tom, Sam's 'boy,' creates a focus on the 'family'. They enjoy trips to Bartholomew Fayre ([2](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/09/02/), [7](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/09/07/)), plays ([10](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/09/10/)), shopping for the home ([16](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/09/16/)), and a lovely family time where 'my wife and Mercer and Tom and I sat till eleven at night, singing, fiddling, and a great joy it is to see me master of so much pleasure in my house, that it is and will be still, I hope, a constant pleasure to me to be at home" ([9](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/09/09/)). Sam spends 10l. on new clothes for Elizabeth, and compliments her new suit of moyre ([5](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/09/05/), [19](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/09/19/)). Elizabeth believes she is with child ([22](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/09/22/)), but by month's end it's clear that she is not. While Sam's jealousy is needlessly piqued by Mr. Pen's visits to Elizabeth ([5](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/09/05/), [14](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/09/14/)) he still indulges himself with his ladies, including news that Betty Lane wants him to assist her in finding a job for her new husband ([5](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/09/05/)) and his secret trysts with Jane Welsh ([11](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/09/11/), [12](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/09/12/), [18](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/09/18/), [19](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/09/19/)). The month ends with a disagreement between Sam and Elizabeth over her household accounts ([29](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/09/29/)). Sam admits to himself that he has been remiss in his work this month ([17](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/09/17/)) although Mr. Andrew's victualling contract brings promises of a payment to Sam of 100l. War preparations continue with Prince Rupert readying the Henrietta ([5](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/09/05/), [6](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/09/06/)) and news of beating the Dutch in Guinny ([29](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/09/29/)).
fields.text_html:
The recent arrival of Mary Mercer, Elizabeth's new gentlewoman, and Tom, Sam's 'boy,' creates a focus on the 'family'. They enjoy trips to Bartholomew Fayre (2, 7), plays (10), shopping for the home (16), and a lovely family time where 'my wife and Mercer and Tom and I sat till eleven at night, singing, fiddling, and a great joy it is to see me master of so much pleasure in my house, that it is and will be still, I hope, a constant pleasure to me to be at home" (9). Sam spends 10l. on new clothes for Elizabeth, and compliments her new suit of moyre (5, 19). Elizabeth believes she is with child (22), but by month's end it's clear that she is not. While Sam's jealousy is needlessly piqued by Mr. Pen's visits to Elizabeth (5, 14) he still indulges himself with his ladies, including news that Betty Lane wants him to assist her in finding a job for her new husband (5) and his secret trysts with Jane Welsh (11, 12, 18, 19). The month ends with a disagreement between Sam and Elizabeth over her household accounts (29).

Sam admits to himself that he has been remiss in his work this month (17) although Mr. Andrew's victualling contract brings promises of a payment to Sam of 100l. War preparations continue with Prince Rupert readying the Henrietta (5, 6) and news of beating the Dutch in Guinny (29).

fields.title: October 1664
fields.text:
Sam works on Warren’s timber contract ([18](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/10/18/), [25](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/10/25/)), Mr. Bridge’s calico contract ([8](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/10/08/), [12](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/10/12/)), the Fishery Committee ([10](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/10/10/), [25](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/10/25/), [29](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/10/29/)) and experiments to test the quality of cordage ([3](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/10/03/)). As Sam welcomes Lord Sandwich on his return ([17](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/10/17/)), the Dutch tension heats up and Rupert writes of the dangers to his fleet in Portsmouth ([24](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/10/24/)). Sam and his extended family enjoy seeing the launch of a new ship ([25](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/10/25/)).

Sam visits his parents while in Brampton ([14](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/10/14/)) and his mother begs him to make peace with his brother John ([15](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/10/15/)).  Elizabeth is angered at Sam for “gadding abroad to look after beauties” ([2](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/10/02/)). This has becoming a more consuming past time to Sam these days with his interactions with Mrs. Lane ([1](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/10/01/)), the barber’s maid Jane ([3](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/10/03/)), Mrs. Bagwell ([3](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/10/03/), [20](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/10/20/)) and an unknown beauty that he follows home from church ([9](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/10/09/)). Mr Crocker brings Sam a globe of glasse intended to help with Sam’s eyesight ([7](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/10/07/)).
fields.text_html:
Sam works on Warren’s timber contract (18, 25), Mr. Bridge’s calico contract (8, 12), the Fishery Committee (10, 25, 29) and experiments to test the quality of cordage (3). As Sam welcomes Lord Sandwich on his return (17), the Dutch tension heats up and Rupert writes of the dangers to his fleet in Portsmouth (24). Sam and his extended family enjoy seeing the launch of a new ship (25).

Sam visits his parents while in Brampton (14) and his mother begs him to make peace with his brother John (15). Elizabeth is angered at Sam for “gadding abroad to look after beauties” (2). This has becoming a more consuming past time to Sam these days with his interactions with Mrs. Lane (1), the barber’s maid Jane (3), Mrs. Bagwell (3, 20) and an unknown beauty that he follows home from church (9). Mr Crocker brings Sam a globe of glasse intended to help with Sam’s eyesight (7).

fields.title: November 1664
fields.text: Sam sees Mr. Coventry off to sea with the Duke of York ([4](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/11/04/), [8](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/11/08/)) and is called before the King’s Cabinet Council and asked questions by the King himself ([9](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/11/09/)). Sam presents a letter to Sir G. Carteret to show to the King regarding his desire to be a Commissioner of the Prize Office ([22](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/11/22/)) and works with Carteret to prepare a well padded account of the cost of the war ([23](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/11/23/)) with hopes that the House will supply desperately needed funding. The House approves 2,500,000l. for the Navy over three years. Sam hears gossip that Lord Sandwich may be sent to be Governor of Tangier ([3](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/11/03/)). He sees the Book of Heraldry and reads the entries of the Duke of Monmouth and Lord Sandwich ([11](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/11/11/)). Susan becomes sick and Sam fears it is the measles or scarlet fever ([10](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/11/10/), [11](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/11/11/)). Tom also has pains which Dr. Holliard diagnoses as a bladder stone ([22](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/11/22/), [23](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/11/23/)). While Sam comments on Mrs. Lane’s sad state ([25](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/11/25/)) his physical relationship with Mrs. Bagwell ([3](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/11/03/), [8](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/11/08/), [15](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/11/15/)) escalates.
fields.text_html:
Sam sees Mr. Coventry off to sea with the Duke of York (4, 8) and is called before the King’s Cabinet Council and asked questions by the King himself (9). Sam presents a letter to Sir G. Carteret to show to the King regarding his desire to be a Commissioner of the Prize Office (22) and works with Carteret to prepare a well padded account of the cost of the war (23) with hopes that the House will supply desperately needed funding. The House approves 2,500,000l. for the Navy over three years.

Sam hears gossip that Lord Sandwich may be sent to be Governor of Tangier (3). He sees the Book of Heraldry and reads the entries of the Duke of Monmouth and Lord Sandwich (11). Susan becomes sick and Sam fears it is the measles or scarlet fever (10, 11). Tom also has pains which Dr. Holliard diagnoses as a bladder stone (22, 23). While Sam comments on Mrs. Lane’s sad state (25) his physical relationship with Mrs. Bagwell (3, 8, 15) escalates.

fields.title: December 1664
fields.text: At the start of the month, Sam is pleased that the Duke of York and Mr. Coventry have returned safely from sea ([3](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/12/03/), [5](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/12/05/)). Other pleasant conversations abound about the great Comet ([15](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/12/15/)): Sam notes that Lord Sandwich ([15](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/12/15/)), the King and Queen ([17](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/12/17/)) have seen it, and eventually he sees it for himself ([24](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/12/24/), [27](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/12/27/)). In a rash act of temper, Sam is angered at Elizabeth. He hits her soundly causing a painful and severely blackened eye ([19](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/12/19/)). Elizabeth, still quite bruised, remains housebound throughout the Christmas holiday period ([25](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/12/25/)) and Sam makes up an excuse for her not attending an unusual dinner invitation from the Battens ([23](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/12/23/), [25](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/12/25/), [26](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/12/26/)). In spite of Sam’s being "vexed at my heart" over what he had done to Elizabeth, it does not stop him from pursuing Mrs. Bagwell. He continues to plot to be with her, finally finding a pleasing "success" when he "invites" himself to their house and then sends her husband away ( [15](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/12/15/), [16](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/12/16/), [19](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/12/19/), [20](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/12/20/)). In regards to finances, Sam has almost fully settled with Tom Trice ([23](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/12/23/)). He buys himself a looking glass for the dining room ([16](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/12/16/), [17](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/12/17/)), some books and a silver sugar box, spoons and forks ([14](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/12/14/), [30](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/12/30/)). A sermon on "duty to parents" ([11](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/12/11/)) seems to have hit home as Sam buys a gift of fruit for his father for Christmas ([14](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/12/14/), [15](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/12/15/)). Sam summarizes his year end status and is pleased to find himself worth 1349l. ([31](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/12/31/)).
fields.text_html:
At the start of the month, Sam is pleased that the Duke of York and Mr. Coventry have returned safely from sea (3, 5). Other pleasant conversations abound about the great Comet (15): Sam notes that Lord Sandwich (15), the King and Queen (17) have seen it, and eventually he sees it for himself (24, 27).

In a rash act of temper, Sam is angered at Elizabeth. He hits her soundly causing a painful and severely blackened eye (19). Elizabeth, still quite bruised, remains housebound throughout the Christmas holiday period (25) and Sam makes up an excuse for her not attending an unusual dinner invitation from the Battens (23, 25, 26). In spite of Sam’s being "vexed at my heart" over what he had done to Elizabeth, it does not stop him from pursuing Mrs. Bagwell. He continues to plot to be with her, finally finding a pleasing "success" when he "invites" himself to their house and then sends her husband away ( 15, 16, 19, 20).

In regards to finances, Sam has almost fully settled with Tom Trice (23). He buys himself a looking glass for the dining room (16, 17), some books and a silver sugar box, spoons and forks (14, 30). A sermon on "duty to parents" (11) seems to have hit home as Sam buys a gift of fruit for his father for Christmas (14, 15). Sam summarizes his year end status and is pleased to find himself worth 1349l. (31).

fields.title: January 1665
fields.text:
A great frost welcomes the New Year ([3](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/01/03/)) as Sam sets about his business of felling lumber ([3](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/01/03/), [12](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/01/12/)), discussing ships to be built ([11](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/01/11/)), meeting with the King and Privy Council ([15](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/01/15/)) and Povy’s accounts ([16](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/01/16/), [18](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/01/18/), [19](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/01/19/), [20](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/01/20/)). The Dutch activity includes Holmes' imprisonment in the Tower ([9](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/01/09/)), confusion over lost ships ([13](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/01/13/), [14](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/01/14/)) and  a letter from Allin with his naval information ([23](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/01/23/)). Sam is pleased to receive money from Sir George Carteret for work related to flags ([28](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/01/28/)).

On the personal side, Sam and Elizabeth argue over their maid Jane ([5](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/01/05/), [6](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/01/06/), [31](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/01/31/)) and Sam continues to be ‘vexed’ by women. He meets Bagwell ([2](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/01/02/), [23](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/01/23/)) and finally, after many attempts, finds himself alone with Gervais’ Jane ([27](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/01/27/)), who has pledged herself to a lowly fiddler ([2](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/01/02/), [13](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/01/13/), [20](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/01/20/)). His cozen Percivall Angier and Dr. Tom Pepys both die this month ([19](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/01/19/)).

Sam enjoys three plays, 'Love in a Tubb' ([4](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/01/04/)), 'The Traytor' ([13](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/01/13/)) and 'Vulpone' ([14](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/01/14/)). He sees the Royal Society Charter and Law book ([9](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/01/09/)),  buys Hooke’s Microscopicall Observations ([20](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/01/20/)), and decides to have the books in his study all bound in the same binding ([18](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/01/18/)).
fields.text_html:
A great frost welcomes the New Year (3) as Sam sets about his business of felling lumber (3, 12), discussing ships to be built (11), meeting with the King and Privy Council (15) and Povy’s accounts (16, 18, 19, 20). The Dutch activity includes Holmes' imprisonment in the Tower (9), confusion over lost ships (13, 14) and a letter from Allin with his naval information (23). Sam is pleased to receive money from Sir George Carteret for work related to flags (28).

On the personal side, Sam and Elizabeth argue over their maid Jane (5, 6, 31) and Sam continues to be ‘vexed’ by women. He meets Bagwell (2, 23) and finally, after many attempts, finds himself alone with Gervais’ Jane (27), who has pledged herself to a lowly fiddler (2, 13, 20). His cozen Percivall Angier and Dr. Tom Pepys both die this month (19).

Sam enjoys three plays, 'Love in a Tubb' (4), 'The Traytor' (13) and 'Vulpone' (14). He sees the Royal Society Charter and Law book (9), buys Hooke’s Microscopicall Observations (20), and decides to have the books in his study all bound in the same binding (18).

fields.title: February 1665
fields.text: With Tangier related work ([2](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/02/02/), [6](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/02/06/), [16](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/02/16/)), Povy’s accounts ([8](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/02/08/), [16](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/02/16/)), Sandwich’s naval fleet manoeuvres ([3](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/02/03/)), false reports of Dutch activity ([23](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/02/23/), [27](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/02/27/)) and the King’s passage of the 2,500,000l. bill ([10](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/02/10/)) in the background, Sam juggles home stresses, indulges in a special interest and enjoys in court gossip. Sam finds discord with Elizabeth ([4](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/02/04/), [28](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/02/28/)) over her handling of the termination of their maid Jane ([3](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/02/03/)). When Batten becomes very ill, Sam ponders if he will live ([6](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/02/06/), [7](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/02/07/)) while the death of Mr. Barlow ([9](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/02/09/)) leaves Sam richer as he is relieved of his payment obligations. In exchange for a letter requesting a better position for her husband, Sam once again delights in Batten’s wife ([14](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/02/14/), [20](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/02/20/)). Sam gladly writes of his new book bindings that it “is now a pleasant sight to see my whole study of almost one binding” ([3](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/02/03/), [5](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/02/05/), [10](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/02/10/)). Sam is proud to take a draught of Portsmouth Harbour by Lord Sandwich off to be made into a chart as a gift for the King, Duke of York and Lord Sandwich himself ([18](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/02/18/), [27](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/02/27/)). Sam is admitted to the Royal Society and is fascinated by the work of Boyle and Hooke ([15](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/02/15/)). Lady Sandwich and Sam discuss potential husbands for her daughters, court stories of masquerades with vizards and the shameful antics of a court beauty Miss Jennings ([3](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/02/03/), [21](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/02/21/)). Sam sees the beginning of the Lord Chancellor’s new home, which has already been nicknamed “Dunkirke House” by the Chancellor’s detractors ([20](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/02/20/)).
fields.text_html:
With Tangier related work (2, 6, 16), Povy’s accounts (8, 16), Sandwich’s naval fleet manoeuvres (3), false reports of Dutch activity (23, 27) and the King’s passage of the 2,500,000l. bill (10) in the background, Sam juggles home stresses, indulges in a special interest and enjoys in court gossip.

Sam finds discord with Elizabeth (4, 28) over her handling of the termination of their maid Jane (3). When Batten becomes very ill, Sam ponders if he will live (6, 7) while the death of Mr. Barlow (9) leaves Sam richer as he is relieved of his payment obligations. In exchange for a letter requesting a better position for her husband, Sam once again delights in Batten’s wife (14, 20).

Sam gladly writes of his new book bindings that it “is now a pleasant sight to see my whole study of almost one binding” (3, 5, 10). Sam is proud to take a draught of Portsmouth Harbour by Lord Sandwich off to be made into a chart as a gift for the King, Duke of York and Lord Sandwich himself (18, 27). Sam is admitted to the Royal Society and is fascinated by the work of Boyle and Hooke (15).

Lady Sandwich and Sam discuss potential husbands for her daughters, court stories of masquerades with vizards and the shameful antics of a court beauty Miss Jennings (3, 21). Sam sees the beginning of the Lord Chancellor’s new home, which has already been nicknamed “Dunkirke House” by the Chancellor’s detractors (20).

fields.title: March 1665
fields.text: War is proclaimed (albeit unofficially) on the Royal Exchange ([4](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/03/04/)) and Sam attends a farewell dinner for Holmes who is released from the Tower ([14](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/03/14/)). The 'London', Sir Lawson’s ship, sinks, killing about 300 people ([8](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/03/08/)). Betty Martin (formerly Lane) gives birth to a son ([9](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/03/09/)) and continues to beg Sam to find a job for her errant husband, who has been keeping a mistress in France. Sam presents Lord Sandwich the chart which Sam had made for him. Lord Sandwich likes it "mightily" ([5](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/03/05/)). Lady Sandwich continues discussions about the potential of Sir George Carteret’s son as a husband for Lady Jemimah. Sam gives Elizabeth 20l. for Easter clothing ([1](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/03/01/)) and has his tailor see to it that his clothing is in order ([21](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/03/21/)). Sharp appearance will no doubt come in handy as Sam finds himself in a position to replace Povy in the highly visible role of Treasurer to the Committee of Tangier. His placement is confirmed with a show of confidence among the Duke and other Committee members ([20](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/03/20/)) and his contract with Povy is completed ([27](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/03/27/)). Sam celebrates his seven year anniversary of the cutting of his stone ([26](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/03/26/)). He also attends several experiments and lectures as a member of the Royal Society ([1](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/03/01/), [8](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/03/08/), [15](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/03/15/), [22](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/03/22/)).
fields.text_html:
War is proclaimed (albeit unofficially) on the Royal Exchange (4) and Sam attends a farewell dinner for Holmes who is released from the Tower (14). The 'London', Sir Lawson’s ship, sinks, killing about 300 people (8). Betty Martin (formerly Lane) gives birth to a son (9) and continues to beg Sam to find a job for her errant husband, who has been keeping a mistress in France.

Sam presents Lord Sandwich the chart which Sam had made for him. Lord Sandwich likes it "mightily" (5). Lady Sandwich continues discussions about the potential of Sir George Carteret’s son as a husband for Lady Jemimah.

Sam gives Elizabeth 20l. for Easter clothing (1) and has his tailor see to it that his clothing is in order (21). Sharp appearance will no doubt come in handy as Sam finds himself in a position to replace Povy in the highly visible role of Treasurer to the Committee of Tangier. His placement is confirmed with a show of confidence among the Duke and other Committee members (20) and his contract with Povy is completed (27).

Sam celebrates his seven year anniversary of the cutting of his stone (26). He also attends several experiments and lectures as a member of the Royal Society (1, 8, 15, 22).

fields.title: April 1665
fields.text:
Much of this month centers on the debts of the Navy and their need for additional funds ([1](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/04/01/), [10](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/04/10/), [12](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/04/12/)). Sam continues to work on issues related to his new role as Treasurer to the Committee of Tangier ([14](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/04/14/), [15](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/04/15/), [18](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/04/18/), [19](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/04/19/)). Naval activities include Sam’s studying of maps ([16](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/04/16/)), payments to the merchant Andrews ([20](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/04/20/), [21](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/04/21/)) and the taking of three Dutch Men-of-War ([16](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/04/16/), [17](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/04/17/)). 

Sam scores a major recognition ([17](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/04/17/), [28](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/04/28/)) when the King sees him in Whitehall and calls him by name and “did discourse with me about the ships in the River; and this is the first time that ever I knew the King did know me personally; so that hereafter I must not go thither, but with expectation to be questioned, and to be ready to give good answers.”  The downside of this recognition is that now Sam needs to be cautious that the King doesn’t spot him ‘in any pleasure’ and upon spotting the King in the park ([24](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/04/24/)) soon after, quickly departs to ensure that he keeps up appearances.
fields.text_html:
Much of this month centers on the debts of the Navy and their need for additional funds (1, 10, 12). Sam continues to work on issues related to his new role as Treasurer to the Committee of Tangier (14, 15, 18, 19). Naval activities include Sam’s studying of maps (16), payments to the merchant Andrews (20, 21) and the taking of three Dutch Men-of-War (16, 17).

Sam scores a major recognition (17, 28) when the King sees him in Whitehall and calls him by name and “did discourse with me about the ships in the River; and this is the first time that ever I knew the King did know me personally; so that hereafter I must not go thither, but with expectation to be questioned, and to be ready to give good answers.” The downside of this recognition is that now Sam needs to be cautious that the King doesn’t spot him ‘in any pleasure’ and upon spotting the King in the park (24) soon after, quickly departs to ensure that he keeps up appearances.

fields.title: May 1665
fields.text: Sam's work includes Tangiers victuals ([7](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/03/07/)), striking 17,500l. of tallys ([12](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/03/12/)), seeking advice regarding the Act for Land Carriages ([13](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/03/13/)) and details of the Dutch fleet ([23](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/03/23/)). A more somber piece of news is that the plague is "growing upon us in this towne" and there is debate over potential remedies for it ([24](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/03/24/)). Sam's mother comes for a visit ([10](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/03/10/)) and has lunch with an old servant and Elizabeth ([23](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/03/23/)). Ever fashionable Sam finds "the convenience of periwigs is so great" that he once again cuts off his hair ([5](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/03/05/)), which cuts a fine figure with his new suit ([21](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/03/21/)). Elizabeth starts to take lessons in limn (a form of illustration) from a Mr. Browne, without the usual arousal of any jealousy on Sam's behalf ([7](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/03/07/), [9](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/03/09/)). Sam writes of John Evelyn's beautiful home and his hive of bees ([1](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/03/01/), [5](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1664/03/05/)). On a more outrageous note, Sam records the early antics of a young Lord Rochester and his kidnapping of Elizabeth Mallet, which leaves Lady Mountagu hoping that this could open the door for a potential wealthy mate for her son, Lord Hinchingbroke.
fields.text_html:
Sam's work includes Tangiers victuals (7), striking 17,500l. of tallys (12), seeking advice regarding the Act for Land Carriages (13) and details of the Dutch fleet (23). A more somber piece of news is that the plague is "growing upon us in this towne" and there is debate over potential remedies for it (24).

Sam's mother comes for a visit (10) and has lunch with an old servant and Elizabeth (23). Ever fashionable Sam finds "the convenience of periwigs is so great" that he once again cuts off his hair (5), which cuts a fine figure with his new suit (21). Elizabeth starts to take lessons in limn (a form of illustration) from a Mr. Browne, without the usual arousal of any jealousy on Sam's behalf (7, 9).

Sam writes of John Evelyn's beautiful home and his hive of bees (1, 5). On a more outrageous note, Sam records the early antics of a young Lord Rochester and his kidnapping of Elizabeth Mallet, which leaves Lady Mountagu hoping that this could open the door for a potential wealthy mate for her son, Lord Hinchingbroke.

fields.title: June 1665
fields.text:
June's flurry of activity begins with unfolding news of the English victory over the Dutch in the Battle of Lowestoft ([3](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/06/03/), [4](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/06/04/), [5](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/06/05/), [8](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/06/08/)). The fallout of the victory includes the good news of the men who performed well in action, like Lord Sandwich ([23](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/06/23/)) along with the sad death of men including the Earl of Falmouth, Earl of Marlborough, Muskerry, Mr. Richard Boyle ([8](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/06/08/)) and later Sir J. Lawson ([25](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/06/25/)). 

The plague continues to infiltrate the town with Sam seeing "two or three houses marked with a red cross upon the doors, and 'Lord have mercy upon us' writ there" ([10](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/06/10/)). By the end of the month the mortality count is 267 ([29](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/06/29/)). Throughout the town people are starting to leave in fear, including the Queen Mother ([17](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/06/17/), [29](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/06/29/)).  Sam's mother, who wanted to extend her stay, also departs ([22](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/06/22/)). 

In the wedding bell area, there is gossip that perhaps Lord Rochester is declared out of hopes for Mrs. Mallet ([6](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/06/06/)), which could bring an opportunity to Lady and Lord Sandwich. At Lord Sandwich's request, Sam begins to act as a go between to arrange the potential match of Lord Sandwich's daughter, Jemimah and Sir George Carteret's son Philip ([23](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/06/23/), [24](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/06/24/), [25](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/06/25/)). The return of Balty ([26](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/06/26/)), along with his new wife, "a pretty modest woman" moves Sam to promise that he will try to find something for him, not necessarily for the sake of Balty he writes, but for his pretty, discreet and humble appearing wife.
fields.text_html:
June's flurry of activity begins with unfolding news of the English victory over the Dutch in the Battle of Lowestoft (3, 4, 5, 8). The fallout of the victory includes the good news of the men who performed well in action, like Lord Sandwich (23) along with the sad death of men including the Earl of Falmouth, Earl of Marlborough, Muskerry, Mr. Richard Boyle (8) and later Sir J. Lawson (25).

The plague continues to infiltrate the town with Sam seeing "two or three houses marked with a red cross upon the doors, and 'Lord have mercy upon us' writ there" (10). By the end of the month the mortality count is 267 (29). Throughout the town people are starting to leave in fear, including the Queen Mother (17, 29). Sam's mother, who wanted to extend her stay, also departs (22).

In the wedding bell area, there is gossip that perhaps Lord Rochester is declared out of hopes for Mrs. Mallet (6), which could bring an opportunity to Lady and Lord Sandwich. At Lord Sandwich's request, Sam begins to act as a go between to arrange the potential match of Lord Sandwich's daughter, Jemimah and Sir George Carteret's son Philip (23, 24, 25). The return of Balty (26), along with his new wife, "a pretty modest woman" moves Sam to promise that he will try to find something for him, not necessarily for the sake of Balty he writes, but for his pretty, discreet and humble appearing wife.

fields.title: July 1665
fields.text:
The plague hits hard this month and London continues to clear out, including Elizabeth and "family" who move to Woolwich. In spite of the spreading disease and related fears  Sam continues to work and visit his lady friends ([11](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/07/11/), [12](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/07/12/), [19](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/07/19/)) without any seeming hesitation. Throughout the month Sam records the rising fatality counts, and notes that  there are few coaches and the streets are "mighty thin of people" ([22](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/07/22/)).  

Sam grooms the awkward Philip Carteret with courting advice ([9](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/07/09/), [15](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/07/15/), [16](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/07/16/), [17](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/07/17/)) and is pleased to know that Lady Jemimah can "readily obey what her father and mother had done" ([17](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/07/17/)). The mothers, Lady Sandwich and Lady Carteret, make plans for the wedding ([12](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/07/12/)) and shorten the engagement period amid fears of the growing plague. A proud Sam, in his new coloured suit, enjoys the wedding ([31](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/07/31/)) and is proud of having facilitated it.   

In family matters, Sam enjoys Elizabeth's fine pictures ([18](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/07/18/), [29](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/07/29/)). Sam jumps on the very recent death of Captain Harman's wife by proposing a marriage between Harman and Pall, but fears that the price will be too steep for him to conclude this arrangement ([21](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/07/21/), [26](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/07/26/)). Once again, Sam ponders the never ending question of what to do for Balty ([25](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/07/25/)).
fields.text_html:
The plague hits hard this month and London continues to clear out, including Elizabeth and "family" who move to Woolwich. In spite of the spreading disease and related fears Sam continues to work and visit his lady friends (11, 12, 19) without any seeming hesitation. Throughout the month Sam records the rising fatality counts, and notes that there are few coaches and the streets are "mighty thin of people" (22).

Sam grooms the awkward Philip Carteret with courting advice (9, 15, 16, 17) and is pleased to know that Lady Jemimah can "readily obey what her father and mother had done" (17). The mothers, Lady Sandwich and Lady Carteret, make plans for the wedding (12) and shorten the engagement period amid fears of the growing plague. A proud Sam, in his new coloured suit, enjoys the wedding (31) and is proud of having facilitated it.

In family matters, Sam enjoys Elizabeth's fine pictures (18, 29). Sam jumps on the very recent death of Captain Harman's wife by proposing a marriage between Harman and Pall, but fears that the price will be too steep for him to conclude this arrangement (21, 26). Once again, Sam ponders the never ending question of what to do for Balty (25).

fields.title: August 1665
fields.text: As the plague rages Sam watches pest coaches pick up a stricken maid ([3](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/08/03/)), sadly recounts the ale-seller Will's loss of his entire family ([8](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/08/08/)), and the death of his physician Dr. Burnett ([25](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/08/25/)). Sam notes, the "discourse in the streets is of death, and nothing else ... the towne is like a place distressed and forsaken" ([30](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/08/30/)) and the plague is such a "cruel thing: this disease making us more cruel to one another than if we are doggs" ([22](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/08/22/)). When Lord Hinchingbroke returns ([4](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/08/04/)) and becomes ill there is a sense of relief that it is "just" small-pox ([16](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/08/16/)). Sam pragmatically re-writes his will ([10](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/08/10/), [11](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/08/11/)) to ensure that his father and Elizabeth are provided for. Leveraging off his new-found status with the Carterets, Sir George shares a rare glimpse of his own relationship with the King ([14](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/08/14/)). In naval activity Sandwich's fleet doesn't fare well in their manoeuvres off of Bergen ([16](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/08/16/), [19](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/08/19/)). Sir George assures Sam ([20](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/08/20/)) that Sandwich was blameless and was only following orders. There is an ominous tone that perhaps this will not prove to be so. In spite of the devastating disease, Sam's irrepressible nature and love of all things beautiful shines through. He is delighted in Elizabeth's developing picture talents ([5](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/08/05/), [7](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/08/07/), [21](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/08/21/)) and gives her the rare gift of a diamond ring ([14](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/08/14/)). In a totally out of character moment he promises Elizabeth a pearl necklace of 60l. within two years if she continues to please him with her paintings. His rising admiration for his wife's artistry doesn't stop his ongoing ogling/dalliances with the ladies ([6](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/08/06/), [8](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/08/08/), [11](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/08/11/), [22](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/08/22/), [23](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/08/23/)). Sam's almost comical erotic dream of Lady Castlemaine ([15](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/08/15/)) provides a fitting summary of the plague times and his idea of and ideal afterlife, "what a happy thing it would be if when we are in our graves (as Shakespeere resembles it) we could dream, and dream but such dreams as this, that then we should not need to be so fearful of death, as we are this plague time." ([15](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/08/15/))
fields.text_html:
As the plague rages Sam watches pest coaches pick up a stricken maid (3), sadly recounts the ale-seller Will's loss of his entire family (8), and the death of his physician Dr. Burnett (25). Sam notes, the "discourse in the streets is of death, and nothing else ... the towne is like a place distressed and forsaken" (30) and the plague is such a "cruel thing: this disease making us more cruel to one another than if we are doggs" (22). When Lord Hinchingbroke returns (4) and becomes ill there is a sense of relief that it is "just" small-pox (16). Sam pragmatically re-writes his will (10, 11) to ensure that his father and Elizabeth are provided for.

Leveraging off his new-found status with the Carterets, Sir George shares a rare glimpse of his own relationship with the King (14). In naval activity Sandwich's fleet doesn't fare well in their manoeuvres off of Bergen (16, 19). Sir George assures Sam (20) that Sandwich was blameless and was only following orders. There is an ominous tone that perhaps this will not prove to be so.

In spite of the devastating disease, Sam's irrepressible nature and love of all things beautiful shines through. He is delighted in Elizabeth's developing picture talents (5, 7, 21) and gives her the rare gift of a diamond ring (14). In a totally out of character moment he promises Elizabeth a pearl necklace of 60l. within two years if she continues to please him with her paintings. His rising admiration for his wife's artistry doesn't stop his ongoing ogling/dalliances with the ladies (6, 8, 11, 22, 23). Sam's almost comical erotic dream of Lady Castlemaine (15) provides a fitting summary of the plague times and his idea of and ideal afterlife, "what a happy thing it would be if when we are in our graves (as Shakespeere resembles it) we could dream, and dream but such dreams as this, that then we should not need to be so fearful of death, as we are this plague time." (15)

fields.title: September 1665
fields.text:
Plague concerns dominate this month with Sam's total removal to Woolwich ([1](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/09/01/)), discussions regarding the disease and how it is spread ([3](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/09/03/)) and the futile burning of fires to stop it ([6](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/09/06/)).  A very passionate story emerges of a man passing his only surviving child stark naked into the arms of a friend for safekeeping with hopes of saving the child from impending death ([3](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/09/03/)). The plague hits Sam's household with the deaths of Will Hewer's and Tom Edwards' fathers ([15](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/09/15/), [21](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/09/21/)), as fear lingers for Elizabeth when her father becomes ill ([10](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/09/10/), [12](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/09/12/)).

While Sam complains of his "masters" that "no one is looking after business" he busies himself with Naval news including activities in Bergen ([5](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/09/05/)), Lord Sandwich's ship military movements ([9](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/09/09/), [10](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/09/10/), [14](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/09/14/)) and the poor state of the fleet regarding provisions and supplies ([18](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/09/18/)). Sam's involvement with Lord Sandwich in the selling of Prizes takes an ominous centre stage ([17](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/09/17/), [18](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/09/18/), [23](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/09/23/), [24](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/09/24/), [25](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/09/25/)) and greatly improves his wealth ([30](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/09/30/)) during this time of great illness and loss to most. 

Sam manages to find some pleasure with a quick tryst ([2](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/09/02/)), his music ([10](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/09/10/), [17](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/09/17/)), his reading of plays ([7](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/09/07/), [16](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/09/16/)), and cards games and billiards ([11](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/09/11/)).  Elizabeth's artistic talent blooms with the completion of her "picture of our Saviour, which is very pretty" ([27](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/09/27/)).
fields.text_html:
Plague concerns dominate this month with Sam's total removal to Woolwich (1), discussions regarding the disease and how it is spread (3) and the futile burning of fires to stop it (6). A very passionate story emerges of a man passing his only surviving child stark naked into the arms of a friend for safekeeping with hopes of saving the child from impending death (3). The plague hits Sam's household with the deaths of Will Hewer's and Tom Edwards' fathers (15, 21), as fear lingers for Elizabeth when her father becomes ill (10, 12).

While Sam complains of his "masters" that "no one is looking after business" he busies himself with Naval news including activities in Bergen (5), Lord Sandwich's ship military movements (9, 10, 14) and the poor state of the fleet regarding provisions and supplies (18). Sam's involvement with Lord Sandwich in the selling of Prizes takes an ominous centre stage (17, 18, 23, 24, 25) and greatly improves his wealth (30) during this time of great illness and loss to most.

Sam manages to find some pleasure with a quick tryst (2), his music (10, 17), his reading of plays (7, 16), and cards games and billiards (11). Elizabeth's artistic talent blooms with the completion of her "picture of our Saviour, which is very pretty" (27).

fields.title: October 1665
fields.text: As the threat of the plague diminishes a new threat surrounds Lord Sandwich's prizes ([1](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/10/01/), [9](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/10/09/), [12](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/10/12/), [16](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/10/16/), [22](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/10/22/), [28](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/10/28/)). An overly busy Sam attends to victualling of Tangier ([4](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/10/04/), [18](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/10/18/)), shares concerns with John Evelyn about providing for sick and wounded seamen ([4](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/10/04/), [7](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/10/07/), [24](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/10/24/)), getting Balty a job ([19](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/10/19/)) and his private accounts ([9](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/10/09/)). Sam agrees with work gossip against him that "I do take too much business upon me, more than I can do, and that therefore some do lie undone. This I confess to my trouble is true, but it arises from my being forced to take so much on me, more than is my proper task to undertake" ([20](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/10/20/)). Work overload doesn't stop Sam from his hopes of the place of "Surveyor-Generall of the Victualling, which will bring me 300l. per annum" ([31](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/10/31/)). Gossip of different nature is shared by Povy who laments the wanton ways of the King and his Court ([16](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/10/16/)). Lord Sandwich 'seconds the motion' by expressing his dismay on the Court politics ([25](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/10/25/)). The King's laziness and wantonness aside, Parliament votes 1,250,000l. towards his war efforts. Sam celebrates his ten year wedding anniversary a day late, noting only his 'extreme good condition of health and estate and honour' but somehow seems to totally forget any mention of Elizabeth ([11](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/10/11/))! Sam reveals an interesting glimpse into his diary writing habit when he writes that he is "late in the office entering my Journall for 8 days past, the greatness of my business hindering me of late to put it down daily, but I have done it now very true and particularly, and hereafter will, I hope, be able to fall into my old way of doing it daily" ([16](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/10/16/)).
fields.text_html:
As the threat of the plague diminishes a new threat surrounds Lord Sandwich's prizes (1, 9, 12, 16, 22, 28). An overly busy Sam attends to victualling of Tangier (4, 18), shares concerns with John Evelyn about providing for sick and wounded seamen (4, 7, 24), getting Balty a job (19) and his private accounts (9).

Sam agrees with work gossip against him that "I do take too much business upon me, more than I can do, and that therefore some do lie undone. This I confess to my trouble is true, but it arises from my being forced to take so much on me, more than is my proper task to undertake" (20). Work overload doesn't stop Sam from his hopes of the place of "Surveyor-Generall of the Victualling, which will bring me 300l. per annum" (31).

Gossip of different nature is shared by Povy who laments the wanton ways of the King and his Court (16). Lord Sandwich 'seconds the motion' by expressing his dismay on the Court politics (25). The King's laziness and wantonness aside, Parliament votes 1,250,000l. towards his war efforts.

Sam celebrates his ten year wedding anniversary a day late, noting only his 'extreme good condition of health and estate and honour' but somehow seems to totally forget any mention of Elizabeth (11)! Sam reveals an interesting glimpse into his diary writing habit when he writes that he is "late in the office entering my Journall for 8 days past, the greatness of my business hindering me of late to put it down daily, but I have done it now very true and particularly, and hereafter will, I hope, be able to fall into my old way of doing it daily" (16).

fields.title: November 1665
fields.text:
Court politics abound as Sam starts the month with an admission that "little merit do prevail in the world, but only favour; and that for myself, chance without merit brought me in; and that diligence only keeps me so" ([1](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/11/01/)). Knowing he is not as highly placed as others and being surrounded by lazy men, Sam tries to remain focused on his work amidst an uprising of sorts of 100 seamen wanting their pay ([4](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/11/04/)). He busies himself with issues surrounding the Tangier boats, prize good profits ([13](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/11/13/)) and the Hambro fleet ([25](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/11/25/)). He does find time to share some enjoyable interactions with John Evelyn ([2](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/11/02/), [5](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/11/05/), [24](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/11/24/)). 

Politics do not shine so brightly on Lord Sandwich who finds himself under attack by many of the factions at Court ([2](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/11/02/), [17](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/11/17/)). Even with the aid of his new "relation" and friend Sir George Carteret, who tries to work the political factions in Sandwich's favor ([6](http://www.pepysdiary.com/archive/1665/11/6/), [27](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/11/27/), [28](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/11/28/)), things seem to be moving against Sandwich. 

Sam is upset that Elizabeth has "put away" Mary ([9](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/11/09/), [10](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/11/10/)). Sam finds time to "make the rounds" with the ladies and partakes of little dalliances with Bagwell's wife, Mrs. Pennington, Sarah and the child Frances Tooker ([8](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/11/08/), [23](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/11/23/), [26](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/11/26/), [27](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/11/27/)). 

The plague seems to be subsiding and Sam is hopeful that the first frost ([22](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/11/22/), [23](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/11/23/)) will be a "perfect cure of the plague". Sadly he hears that Luellin is dead of it ([20](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/11/20/)), and in a letter from his father he also learns that his Aunt Bell has also succumbed to the deadly disease.
fields.text_html:
Court politics abound as Sam starts the month with an admission that "little merit do prevail in the world, but only favour; and that for myself, chance without merit brought me in; and that diligence only keeps me so" (1). Knowing he is not as highly placed as others and being surrounded by lazy men, Sam tries to remain focused on his work amidst an uprising of sorts of 100 seamen wanting their pay (4). He busies himself with issues surrounding the Tangier boats, prize good profits (13) and the Hambro fleet (25). He does find time to share some enjoyable interactions with John Evelyn (2, 5, 24).

Politics do not shine so brightly on Lord Sandwich who finds himself under attack by many of the factions at Court (2, 17). Even with the aid of his new "relation" and friend Sir George Carteret, who tries to work the political factions in Sandwich's favor (6, 27, 28), things seem to be moving against Sandwich.

Sam is upset that Elizabeth has "put away" Mary (9, 10). Sam finds time to "make the rounds" with the ladies and partakes of little dalliances with Bagwell's wife, Mrs. Pennington, Sarah and the child Frances Tooker (8, 23, 26, 27).

The plague seems to be subsiding and Sam is hopeful that the first frost (22, 23) will be a "perfect cure of the plague". Sadly he hears that Luellin is dead of it (20), and in a letter from his father he also learns that his Aunt Bell has also succumbed to the deadly disease.

fields.title: December 1665
fields.text: In December Sam focuses on Tangier and his victualling business ([1](http://www.pepysdiary.com/archive/1665/12/1/), [2](http://www.pepysdiary.com/archive/1665/12/2/), [8](http://www.pepysdiary.com/archive/1665/12/8/), [11](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/12/11/), [13](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/12/13/), [27](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/12/27/)). By the middle of the month he admits that his accounts are a mess and he spends Christmas Day pulling them into a better condition. The plague seems to increase for a while ([13](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/12/13/), [17](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/12/17/), [20](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/12/20/), [22](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/12/22/)) but finally Sam sees a decline ([29](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/12/29/)). In spite of the illness still lingering Elizabeth and her maids move back to London ([2](http://www.pepysdiary.com/archive/1665/12/2/)), unknowingly leaving Sam free to frolic with Madam Penington ([4](http://www.pepysdiary.com/archive/1665/12/4/), [17](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/12/17/), [20](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/12/20/)). As a result of Sam's recommendation, Balty gets a job with the Duke of Albemarle's guards. Although glad that his stature won Balty a position, an astute Sam now has to worry that Balty "may carry himself that I may receive no disgrace by him" ([4](http://www.pepysdiary.com/archive/1665/12/4/)). Sam's Christmas is spent at church where he watches a wedding ceremony and wonders how "strange to see what delight we married people have to see these poor fools decoyed into our condition, every man and woman gazing and smiling at them ([25](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/12/25/))." Sam ends his year declaring that "I have never lived so merrily (besides that I never got so much) as I have done this plague time", with his net worth increasing from 1300l. to 4400l.. Although prize money issues still carry on for Sam ([3](http://www.pepysdiary.com/archive/1665/12/3/), [5](http://www.pepysdiary.com/archive/1665/12/5/), [13](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/12/13/)) the year ends sadly for Lord Sandwich ([6](http://www.pepysdiary.com/archive/1665/12/6/), [7](http://www.pepysdiary.com/archive/1665/12/7/), [8](http://www.pepysdiary.com/archive/1665/12/8/)).
