Sam records that "The great evil this year, and the only one indeed, is the fall of my Lord Sandwich, whose mistake about the prizes has undone him, I believe, as to interest at Court, though sent (for a little palliating it) Embassador to Spayne, which he is now fitting himself for." Sam ends the year with hopes for the plague to truly end and a bright eye for the return of business as usual.
fields.text_html:
In December Sam focuses on Tangier and his victualling business (1, 2, 8, 11, 13, 27). By the middle of the month he admits that his accounts are a mess and he spends Christmas Day pulling them into a better condition.

The plague seems to increase for a while (13, 17, 20, 22) but finally Sam sees a decline (29). In spite of the illness still lingering Elizabeth and her maids move back to London (2), unknowingly leaving Sam free to frolic with Madam Penington (4, 17, 20).

As a result of Sam's recommendation, Balty gets a job with the Duke of Albemarle's guards. Although glad that his stature won Balty a position, an astute Sam now has to worry that Balty "may carry himself that I may receive no disgrace by him" (4).

Sam's Christmas is spent at church where he watches a wedding ceremony and wonders how "strange to see what delight we married people have to see these poor fools decoyed into our condition, every man and woman gazing and smiling at them (25)."

Sam ends his year declaring that "I have never lived so merrily (besides that I never got so much) as I have done this plague time", with his net worth increasing from 1300l. to 4400l.. Although prize money issues still carry on for Sam (3, 5, 13) the year ends sadly for Lord Sandwich (6, 7, 8). Sam records that "The great evil this year, and the only one indeed, is the fall of my Lord Sandwich, whose mistake about the prizes has undone him, I believe, as to interest at Court, though sent (for a little palliating it) Embassador to Spayne, which he is now fitting himself for." Sam ends the year with hopes for the plague to truly end and a bright eye for the return of business as usual.

fields.title: January 1666
fields.text: Sam begins the New Year in the difficult position of being torn between political Navy factions. On one hand, he has loyalties to both Lord Sandwich, whose reputation has been tarnished by the Prize affairs ([12](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1666/01/12/), [17](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1666/01/17/), [28](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1666/01/28/)), and to Sir George Carteret, who is rumoured to be losing his position to Lord Craven ([7](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1666/01/07/), [26](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1666/01/26/)). On the other side Sam is viewed favourably by their enemy Sir W. Coventry ([6](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1666/01/06/)). "To see what difficulty I stand, that I dare not walk with Sir W. Coventry, for fear my Lord of Sir G. Carteret should see me; nor with either of them, for fear Sir W. Coventry should" ([28](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1666/01/28/)). Feeling alone he admits that "I must now stand upon my own legs" ([7](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1666/01/07/)). A very bright note is that both the King ([28](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1666/01/28/)) and Duke of York ([28](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1666/01/28/), [29](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1666/01/29/)) are highly complimentary and supportive of Sam and his work, something he shares details of with Elizabeth ([30](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1666/01/30/)). On a positive note, Elizabeth works "like a horse" all month redecorating their bedchamber ([7](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1666/01/07/), [9](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1666/01/09/), [26](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1666/01/26/)) with very pleasing results. Sam, through Kate Joyce and her husband, seems to be making some progress in arranging a match between Pall and Harman ([14](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1666/01/14/), [25](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1666/01/25/)). Most satisfying of all is that by month end Sandwich's 1000l. bond to Sam's cousin (to which Sam was bound in the event that Sandwich defaulted) has been paid by Lord Sandwich from his prize money.
fields.text_html:
Sam begins the New Year in the difficult position of being torn between political Navy factions. On one hand, he has loyalties to both Lord Sandwich, whose reputation has been tarnished by the Prize affairs (12, 17, 28), and to Sir George Carteret, who is rumoured to be losing his position to Lord Craven (7, 26). On the other side Sam is viewed favourably by their enemy Sir W. Coventry (6). "To see what difficulty I stand, that I dare not walk with Sir W. Coventry, for fear my Lord of Sir G. Carteret should see me; nor with either of them, for fear Sir W. Coventry should" (28). Feeling alone he admits that "I must now stand upon my own legs" (7). A very bright note is that both the King (28) and Duke of York (28, 29) are highly complimentary and supportive of Sam and his work, something he shares details of with Elizabeth (30).

On a positive note, Elizabeth works "like a horse" all month redecorating their bedchamber (7, 9, 26) with very pleasing results. Sam, through Kate Joyce and her husband, seems to be making some progress in arranging a match between Pall and Harman (14, 25). Most satisfying of all is that by month end Sandwich's 1000l. bond to Sam's cousin (to which Sam was bound in the event that Sandwich defaulted) has been paid by Lord Sandwich from his prize money.

fields.title: February 1666
fields.text:
February sees a return to normal as Sam reconnects with those he hasn't seen during the plague. He returns to church with Elizabeth ([4](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/02/04/)), rearranges the books in his chamber to their pre-plague places ([7](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/02/07/)), notes the return of Lady Batten ([5](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/02/05/)), Sir Thomas Harvey ([10](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/02/10/)) and Mr. Caesar his boy's lute master ([12](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/02/12/)). Sam watches the newly returned Queen and her ladies playing cards and notes that she looks well in spite of her recent miscarriage ([19](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/02/19/)). 

As Sam's life settles in Lord Sandwich prepares to embark on a new phase of his career, as Ambassador to Spain ([2](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/02/02/), [16](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/02/16/), [23](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/02/23/), [25](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/02/25/)). Sam continues the delicate balance of the politics of the Sandwich, Carteret vs. Coventry situation ([12](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/02/12/), [14](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/02/14/), [26](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/02/26/)). Other business surrounding the Navy continues ([2](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/02/02/), [6](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/02/06/), [14](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/02/14/)) and Sam engages with the Houbland family ([8](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/02/08/), [9](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/02/09/), [16](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/02/16/)) with hopes of gaining some payments along the way.

Elizabeth busies herself this month with the portrait painter Mr. Hales, who works on her portrait in the style of St. Katherine ([14](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/02/14/), [15](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/02/15/), [27](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/02/27/)). Sam continues with his efforts to marry off his sister Pall ([11](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/02/11/)), notes his brother John's desire for a spiritual promotion ([21](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/02/21/)), has a sad visit from Uncle Wight ([18](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/02/18/)) and hears of the death of his Aunt James ([4](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/02/04/)). 

Sam's life may well be back to normal as he finds himself "beset with people to spend me money" ([20](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1665/02/20/)) complaining of the expense of becoming the godfather to Captain Ferrer's daughter Katherine, the Valentine of Mrs. Pierce, the host of little Miss Tooker, and the source of a potential loan to Mrs. Lane.
fields.text_html:
February sees a return to normal as Sam reconnects with those he hasn't seen during the plague. He returns to church with Elizabeth (4), rearranges the books in his chamber to their pre-plague places (7), notes the return of Lady Batten (5), Sir Thomas Harvey (10) and Mr. Caesar his boy's lute master (12). Sam watches the newly returned Queen and her ladies playing cards and notes that she looks well in spite of her recent miscarriage (19).

As Sam's life settles in Lord Sandwich prepares to embark on a new phase of his career, as Ambassador to Spain (2, 16, 23, 25). Sam continues the delicate balance of the politics of the Sandwich, Carteret vs. Coventry situation (12, 14, 26). Other business surrounding the Navy continues (2, 6, 14) and Sam engages with the Houbland family (8, 9, 16) with hopes of gaining some payments along the way.

Elizabeth busies herself this month with the portrait painter Mr. Hales, who works on her portrait in the style of St. Katherine (14, 15, 27). Sam continues with his efforts to marry off his sister Pall (11), notes his brother John's desire for a spiritual promotion (21), has a sad visit from Uncle Wight (18) and hears of the death of his Aunt James (4).

Sam's life may well be back to normal as he finds himself "beset with people to spend me money" (20) complaining of the expense of becoming the godfather to Captain Ferrer's daughter Katherine, the Valentine of Mrs. Pierce, the host of little Miss Tooker, and the source of a potential loan to Mrs. Lane.

fields.title: March 1666
fields.text:
With Lord Sandwich on his way to Spain, Sam sets out to re-establish his 'good' relationships with the Duke of York ([7](http://www.pepysdiary.com/archive/1666/03/7/)) and Mr. Coventry ([6](http://www.pepysdiary.com/archive/1666/03/6/), [7](http://www.pepysdiary.com/archive/1666/03/7/)) and even suffers through a "dirty, nasty dinner" with Albemarle ([9](http://www.pepysdiary.com/archive/1666/03/9/), [25](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1666/03/25/)) to do so. 

Issues surrounding accounts overwhelm Sam this month. He advised Sir George Carteret to come clean and be very open with the Board review of his accounts. Meanwhile Sam struggles with his own personal and public accounts and finds his head 'confounded' after days of struggling with them ([25](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1666/03/25/)). 

Sam thoroughly enjoys Elizabeth's new portrait and starts to sit for his own ([17](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1666/03/17/)). He finds a job for brother-in-law Balty, albeit a hazardous one as a Muster-Master at sea. He continues to negotiate with Harman as a potential husband for Pall although his father proposes a marriage with an unsuitable, albeit rather well off, drunk. He also receives news that his father is being sued for a debt of Tom's ([19](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1666/03/19/), [21](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1666/03/21/)).

Perhaps the highlight of the month is found in the self reflections that Sam shares on the [9th](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1666/03/09/) and [10th](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1666/03/10/) as he writes quite honestly of himself: "I do see that my nature is not to be quite conquered, but will esteem pleasure above all things, though yet in the middle of it, it has reluctances after my business, which is neglected by my following my pleasure. However musique and women I cannot but give way to, what my business is" , and "The truth is, I do indulge myself a little the more in pleasure, knowing that this is the proper age of my life to do it; and out of my observation that most men that do thrive in the world, do forget to take pleasure during the time that they are getting their estate, but reserve that till they have got one, and then it is too late for them to enjoy it with any pleasure".
fields.text_html:
With Lord Sandwich on his way to Spain, Sam sets out to re-establish his 'good' relationships with the Duke of York (7) and Mr. Coventry (6, 7) and even suffers through a "dirty, nasty dinner" with Albemarle (9, 25) to do so.

Issues surrounding accounts overwhelm Sam this month. He advised Sir George Carteret to come clean and be very open with the Board review of his accounts. Meanwhile Sam struggles with his own personal and public accounts and finds his head 'confounded' after days of struggling with them (25).

Sam thoroughly enjoys Elizabeth's new portrait and starts to sit for his own (17). He finds a job for brother-in-law Balty, albeit a hazardous one as a Muster-Master at sea. He continues to negotiate with Harman as a potential husband for Pall although his father proposes a marriage with an unsuitable, albeit rather well off, drunk. He also receives news that his father is being sued for a debt of Tom's (19, 21).

Perhaps the highlight of the month is found in the self reflections that Sam shares on the 9th and 10th as he writes quite honestly of himself: "I do see that my nature is not to be quite conquered, but will esteem pleasure above all things, though yet in the middle of it, it has reluctances after my business, which is neglected by my following my pleasure. However musique and women I cannot but give way to, what my business is" , and "The truth is, I do indulge myself a little the more in pleasure, knowing that this is the proper age of my life to do it; and out of my observation that most men that do thrive in the world, do forget to take pleasure during the time that they are getting their estate, but reserve that till they have got one, and then it is too late for them to enjoy it with any pleasure".

fields.title: April 1666
fields.text: Elizabeth visits Brampton to gather details about a potential husband for Pall ([4](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1666/04/04/), [19](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1666/04/19/)). Sam visits with Balty who prepares for his departure to sea as a Muster-Master aboard the Henry ([27](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1666/04/27/)). Sam graciously sends some of his ruling work to Elizabeth's father, which will provide him with much needed money ([28](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1666/04/28/)). Sam writes a rather sharp letter to his brother John, the first he's written to him since he become angry with him ([28](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1666/04/28/)). The most exciting family matter is that Sam acts on his August 1665 promise to buy Elizabeth a pearl necklace. Sam finds himself in a rather contented state in his marriage these days and finds himself "melancholy in the absence of my wife" ([6](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1666/04/06/)) while she is away. His original promise was for a 60l. necklace, but he seems content to lay out 80l. Sam is pleased to record his net worth at 5200l. by month end. With the Court in mourning at the death of Queen Catherine's mother Sam dons his black coat ([22](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1666/04/22/)) and notes how ordinary and plain Lady Castlemaine is in her black morning attire without her finery and makeup. The young Mrs. Stewart, however, still gets the nod of approval on her looks, even in her mourning attire ([21](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1666/04/21/)).
fields.text_html:
Elizabeth visits Brampton to gather details about a potential husband for Pall (4, 19). Sam visits with Balty who prepares for his departure to sea as a Muster-Master aboard the Henry (27). Sam graciously sends some of his ruling work to Elizabeth's father, which will provide him with much needed money (28). Sam writes a rather sharp letter to his brother John, the first he's written to him since he become angry with him (28).

The most exciting family matter is that Sam acts on his August 1665 promise to buy Elizabeth a pearl necklace. Sam finds himself in a rather contented state in his marriage these days and finds himself "melancholy in the absence of my wife" (6) while she is away. His original promise was for a 60l. necklace, but he seems content to lay out 80l. Sam is pleased to record his net worth at 5200l. by month end.

With the Court in mourning at the death of Queen Catherine's mother Sam dons his black coat (22) and notes how ordinary and plain Lady Castlemaine is in her black morning attire without her finery and makeup. The young Mrs. Stewart, however, still gets the nod of approval on her looks, even in her mourning attire (21).

fields.title: May 1666
fields.text:
Health matters start with the illness of little Su, Elizabeth's 'bad cheek' ([8](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1666/05/08/), [12](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1666/05/12/)), and end with Sam's sore eye ([30](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1666/05/30/)). Most upsetting is the still-born baby delivered by Balty's wife, which Sam takes in stride as "there is no reason to be sorry because his staying without a child will be better for him and for her" ([30](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1666/05/30/)).

Sam enjoys Elizabeth and the ladies but faces Elizabeth's wrath as she calls Mrs. Pierce and Mrs. Knipp "whores" ([9](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1666/05/09/)). Later, while discussing "the ladies" with Elizabeth, Sam admits that  he is to blame for her upset here as Elizabeth "do find with reason, that in the company of Pierce, Knipp, or other women that I love, I do not value her, or mind her as I ought" ([12](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1666/05/12/)). 

Work worries surround Sam's business, where "his defect in my duty of the Victualling, which lies upon me as a burden, till I get myself into a better posture therein, and hinders me and cast down my courage in very thing else that belongs to me, and the jealousy I have of Sir W. Coventry's being displeased with me about it" ([31](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1666/05/31/)).
fields.text_html:
Health matters start with the illness of little Su, Elizabeth's 'bad cheek' (8, 12), and end with Sam's sore eye (30). Most upsetting is the still-born baby delivered by Balty's wife, which Sam takes in stride as "there is no reason to be sorry because his staying without a child will be better for him and for her" (30).

Sam enjoys Elizabeth and the ladies but faces Elizabeth's wrath as she calls Mrs. Pierce and Mrs. Knipp "whores" (9). Later, while discussing "the ladies" with Elizabeth, Sam admits that he is to blame for her upset here as Elizabeth "do find with reason, that in the company of Pierce, Knipp, or other women that I love, I do not value her, or mind her as I ought" (12).

Work worries surround Sam's business, where "his defect in my duty of the Victualling, which lies upon me as a burden, till I get myself into a better posture therein, and hinders me and cast down my courage in very thing else that belongs to me, and the jealousy I have of Sir W. Coventry's being displeased with me about it" (31).

fields.title: June 1666
fields.text:
The guns of the fleet are heard as battle against the Dutch unfolds ([2](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1666/06/02/), [4](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1666/06/04/)). Early excitement about a win turns to disappointment at a loss due to the division of the fleet ([7](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1666/06/07/), [8](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1666/06/08/), [24](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1666/06/24/)). Balty escapes unharmed ([8](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1666/06/08/)) but Sir William Clerke ([7](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1666/06/07/)), Sir Christopher Mings ([10](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1666/06/10/)) and Sir William Barkeley ([16](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1666/06/16/)) are among the many that lose their lives.  Fallout and blame are the fodder of gossip with finger pointing at Albemarle's poor leadership, the poor morale of the seamen and general bad management. Holmes, Spragg and Smith ([10](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1666/06/10/)) are viewed as those that carry out the business of true fighting.

As the battle news and fallout unfolds, Sam entertains his father and brings him to Hales to have his portrait done ([6](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1666/06/06/), [11](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1666/06/11/), [14](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1666/06/14/)). Sam and his father discuss business ([17](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1666/06/17/)) including the latter's estate, Pall's proposed marriage arrangements, and his brother John who is still in Sam's bad graces ([17](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1666/06/17/)).  By month end much is settled with his father, but Sam's "extended family" has an upset with the temporary departure of Mercer ([23](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1666/06/23/)) after a falling out with Elizabeth.
fields.text_html:
The guns of the fleet are heard as battle against the Dutch unfolds (2, 4). Early excitement about a win turns to disappointment at a loss due to the division of the fleet (7, 8, 24). Balty escapes unharmed (8) but Sir William Clerke (7), Sir Christopher Mings (10) and Sir William Barkeley (16) are among the many that lose their lives. Fallout and blame are the fodder of gossip with finger pointing at Albemarle's poor leadership, the poor morale of the seamen and general bad management. Holmes, Spragg and Smith (10) are viewed as those that carry out the business of true fighting.

As the battle news and fallout unfolds, Sam entertains his father and brings him to Hales to have his portrait done (6, 11, 14). Sam and his father discuss business (17) including the latter's estate, Pall's proposed marriage arrangements, and his brother John who is still in Sam's bad graces (17). By month end much is settled with his father, but Sam's "extended family" has an upset with the temporary departure of Mercer (23) after a falling out with Elizabeth.

fields.title: July 1666
fields.text:
Unruly men are pressed to sea ([2](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1666/07/02/)) and the wives of those who have been held prisoner in Holland unnerve Sam as they shout out in anger and beg for money ([10](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1666/07/10/)). Balty is among those who leaves for sea ([19](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1666/07/19/)). The fighting begins along with worries about the state of the young gentlemen captains and their lack of ability ([25](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1666/07/25/)).  Sam's worry is for naught with news of a victory as the English Navy beats them into the Weelings ([29](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1666/07/29/)). Sam believes that there is a double victory at the death of De Ruyter but is disappointed to find this rumour is false ([31](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1666/07/31/)). While the brave fight Creed tells Sam that things are mighty dull at Court, where they lounge in bed and have no drive to do any work or any cares to be productive ([7](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1666/07/07/)). 

With good news comes the bad as Sam is asked to be the godfather to Mrs. Knipp's boy ([6](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1666/07/06/)) followed by the sad news of the death of Mrs. Pierce's newly born son ([26](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1666/07/26/)). Mercer is back in the fold ([5](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1666/07/05/)) and all settles down with Sam's extended family this month.
fields.text_html:
Unruly men are pressed to sea (2) and the wives of those who have been held prisoner in Holland unnerve Sam as they shout out in anger and beg for money (10). Balty is among those who leaves for sea (19). The fighting begins along with worries about the state of the young gentlemen captains and their lack of ability (25). Sam's worry is for naught with news of a victory as the English Navy beats them into the Weelings (29). Sam believes that there is a double victory at the death of De Ruyter but is disappointed to find this rumour is false (31). While the brave fight Creed tells Sam that things are mighty dull at Court, where they lounge in bed and have no drive to do any work or any cares to be productive (7).

With good news comes the bad as Sam is asked to be the godfather to Mrs. Knipp's boy (6) followed by the sad news of the death of Mrs. Pierce's newly born son (26). Mercer is back in the fold (5) and all settles down with Sam's extended family this month.

fields.title: August 1666
fields.text:
Sadly the plague advances in Greenwich, Deptford and Deal as many escape for London ([6](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1666/08/06/), [9](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1666/08/09/)). New plague deaths are also reported locally. Sir Minnes becomes ill of ague ([20](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1666/08/20/), [22](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1666/08/22/)) and Sam fears Sir W. Pen may become Minnes' replacement if he dies. 

Sam and Elizabeth are at odds most of the month with arguments over Mrs. Knipp and Mrs. Pierce ([6](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1666/08/06/)), Elizabeth's unauthorised expenditure on a handkerchief ([12](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1666/08/12/)) and her "snappish" ways ([21](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1666/08/21/)). Sam's only pleasure is in her painting of the Virgin head ([9](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1666/08/09/), [11](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1666/08/11/)) which he admires. 

Naval news includes "Holmes' bonfire" which is his famous burning of the enemy's harbour and houses in Vile and Schelling ([15](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1666/08/15/)). A friendly bet between Carteret, Batten and Sam about the action against the Dutch takes place ([16](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1666/08/16/)). On a more stressful note, Sam is pulled in front of the King with little warning and must report on the want of victuals for the fleet ([26](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1666/08/26/)). A few days later the King receives a letter from Prince Rupert and the Duke of Albemarle complaining about their need for supplies which references Sam's accounts of what has been sent, which fall short of their needs ([28](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1666/08/28/)).
fields.text_html:
Sadly the plague advances in Greenwich, Deptford and Deal as many escape for London (6, 9). New plague deaths are also reported locally. Sir Minnes becomes ill of ague (20, 22) and Sam fears Sir W. Pen may become Minnes' replacement if he dies.

Sam and Elizabeth are at odds most of the month with arguments over Mrs. Knipp and Mrs. Pierce (6), Elizabeth's unauthorised expenditure on a handkerchief (12) and her "snappish" ways (21). Sam's only pleasure is in her painting of the Virgin head (9, 11) which he admires.

Naval news includes "Holmes' bonfire" which is his famous burning of the enemy's harbour and houses in Vile and Schelling (15). A friendly bet between Carteret, Batten and Sam about the action against the Dutch takes place (16). On a more stressful note, Sam is pulled in front of the King with little warning and must report on the want of victuals for the fleet (26). A few days later the King receives a letter from Prince Rupert and the Duke of Albemarle complaining about their need for supplies which references Sam's accounts of what has been sent, which fall short of their needs (28).

fields.title: September 1666
fields.text:
Jane awakens Sam and Elizabeth telling them of a "great fire" that she saw in the City ([2](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1666/09/02/)). Sam leaves to White Hall with details of the fire to present to the King and Duke of York. Sam tells the King that unless he pulls down houses nothing will stop the fire. The King tells Sam to bring the Lord Mayor a command to spare no houses, but to no real avail as the fire begins to engulf the city over the next several days.

As the fire escalates Sam secures his belongings, carrying money and plate away in a cart loaned by Lady Batten, burying wine and Parmesan cheese in the garden ([4](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1666/09/04/)) and locking up his gold ([5](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1666/09/05/)) with strict orders for Elizabeth not to leave it alone. Over the next few days people and their goods are juggled throughout the city, from one "safe" place to another. Sam's home remains as the fire subsides and he starts the slow process of moving back ([13](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1666/09/13/)) and re-organising his home. In spite of all the work and dishevelled activity Sam is back in good form by month end ([22](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1666/09/22/)) and pleased that his home is in as good condition as it ever was before the fire. Many in London are not in good shape and John Evelyn reports to Sam on the dismal state of the poor ([22](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1666/09/22/)) and the lack of respect for the King.
fields.text_html:
Jane awakens Sam and Elizabeth telling them of a "great fire" that she saw in the City (2). Sam leaves to White Hall with details of the fire to present to the King and Duke of York. Sam tells the King that unless he pulls down houses nothing will stop the fire. The King tells Sam to bring the Lord Mayor a command to spare no houses, but to no real avail as the fire begins to engulf the city over the next several days.

As the fire escalates Sam secures his belongings, carrying money and plate away in a cart loaned by Lady Batten, burying wine and Parmesan cheese in the garden (4) and locking up his gold (5) with strict orders for Elizabeth not to leave it alone. Over the next few days people and their goods are juggled throughout the city, from one "safe" place to another. Sam's home remains as the fire subsides and he starts the slow process of moving back (13) and re-organising his home. In spite of all the work and dishevelled activity Sam is back in good form by month end (22) and pleased that his home is in as good condition as it ever was before the fire. Many in London are not in good shape and John Evelyn reports to Sam on the dismal state of the poor (22) and the lack of respect for the King.

fields.title: November 1666
fields.text:
The "ill condition of things ... is the common subject of all men's discourse and fears now-a-days" ([12](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1666/11/12/)) with concerns of lack of money ([27](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1666/11/27/)) and the sorry state of the Navy ([17](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1666/11/17/), [18](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1666/11/18/), [25](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1666/11/25/)), and so Sam prepares his controversial "Great Letter" to the Duke of York detailing the dismal financial state of the Navy ([16](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1666/11/16/), [17](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1666/11/17/), [18](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1666/11/18/)).

A fire erupts at White Hall and the whole city is once again in alarm ([9](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1666/11/09/)), but this fire is contained. The Committee examining the Great Fire of September starts to place the blame on papist plots ([5](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1666/11/05/)). Meanwhile the King starts to gather maps and information to look at the rebuilding of London ([22](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1666/11/22/)).

Great festivities take place on the Queen's birthday with all of the handsome courtiers and beautiful ladies dressed in their finery and dancing ([15](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1666/11/15/)).   On another fashion note there is gossip that the King of France has slighted King Charles II's newest fashion, the vest, by dressing all of his footmen in vest attire. Although Sam sees it as an "ingenious kind of affront; yet it makes me angry, to see that the King of England is become so little as to have the affront offered him" ([22](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1666/11/22/)). It seems that the King is lacking respect not only within his own country, but from afar.
fields.text_html:
The "ill condition of things ... is the common subject of all men's discourse and fears now-a-days" (12) with concerns of lack of money (27) and the sorry state of the Navy (17, 18, 25), and so Sam prepares his controversial "Great Letter" to the Duke of York detailing the dismal financial state of the Navy (16, 17, 18).

A fire erupts at White Hall and the whole city is once again in alarm (9), but this fire is contained. The Committee examining the Great Fire of September starts to place the blame on papist plots (5). Meanwhile the King starts to gather maps and information to look at the rebuilding of London (22).

Great festivities take place on the Queen's birthday with all of the handsome courtiers and beautiful ladies dressed in their finery and dancing (15). On another fashion note there is gossip that the King of France has slighted King Charles II's newest fashion, the vest, by dressing all of his footmen in vest attire. Although Sam sees it as an "ingenious kind of affront; yet it makes me angry, to see that the King of England is become so little as to have the affront offered him" (22). It seems that the King is lacking respect not only within his own country, but from afar.

fields.title: December 1666
fields.text:
Many themes continue this month as the year comes to an end. The Catholics defend themselves in <cite>The Catholique's Apology</cite> ([1](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1666/12/01/)) which Sam finds well written. A strangely ominous article that appeared in the <cite>London Gazette</cite> in April seems to add to the possible plots behind the Great Fire ([13](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1666/12/13/), [14](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1666/12/14/)). 

The King's court causes ongoing gossip with the Duke of Monmouth's claims that he is the King's rightful son ([16](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1666/12/16/)). The £30,000 debts of Lady Castlemaine are paid off by the King ([12](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1666/12/12/)). Although her ranking in the King's affections seems to be falling, Sam is thrilled to purchase three prints of Lady Castlemaine and have one framed for himself ([1](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1666/12/01/), [21](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1666/12/21/)). 

Sam hears that Lord Sandwich will be brought home ([13](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1666/12/13/)) and writes him a long overdue letter ([17](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1666/12/17/)).  On the work front lack of money issues continue. A revolt of 1000 seamen brings fear to Sam ([19](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1666/12/19/)) but the Duke of Albemarle steps in with forces to quell the uprising. 

Sam starts to experience eye troubles and buys himself some spectacles with the hope that these will ease his pain ([24](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1666/12/24/), [27](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1666/12/27/), [29](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1666/12/27/)). He writes his usual astute year-end summary showing overall disgust with the "public" state of the Kingdom but thankfulness for his robust estate and the well being of his family ([31](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1666/12/31/)).
fields.text_html:
Many themes continue this month as the year comes to an end. The Catholics defend themselves in The Catholique's Apology (1) which Sam finds well written. A strangely ominous article that appeared in the London Gazette in April seems to add to the possible plots behind the Great Fire (13, 14).

The King's court causes ongoing gossip with the Duke of Monmouth's claims that he is the King's rightful son (16). The £30,000 debts of Lady Castlemaine are paid off by the King (12). Although her ranking in the King's affections seems to be falling, Sam is thrilled to purchase three prints of Lady Castlemaine and have one framed for himself (1, 21).

Sam hears that Lord Sandwich will be brought home (13) and writes him a long overdue letter (17). On the work front lack of money issues continue. A revolt of 1000 seamen brings fear to Sam (19) but the Duke of Albemarle steps in with forces to quell the uprising.

Sam starts to experience eye troubles and buys himself some spectacles with the hope that these will ease his pain (24, 27, 29). He writes his usual astute year-end summary showing overall disgust with the "public" state of the Kingdom but thankfulness for his robust estate and the well being of his family (31).

fields.title: January 1667
fields.text:
Sam's yearly vows, which include the usual restrictions on theatre visits ([6](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1666/01/06/), [7](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1666/01/07/)) are swiftly broken when he enjoys "The Numerous Lieutenant" ([23](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1666/01/23/)) and is delighted to kiss the actress Nell Gwyn. Sam entertains and shows off his wonderful silver to his guests ([4](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1666/01/04/)), although some realised that he may have acquired his flagons by dubious means ([11](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1666/01/11/)).

Elizabeth talks to Sam's sister Pall about a potential marriage to Will Hewer, only to get a polite "thanks, but no thanks" ([16](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1666/01/16/), [18](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1666/01/18/)) . Sam gets some hard-hitting news to his wallet, when the Poll Tax Bill passes ([25](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1666/01/25/)). Sam hopes that the complex Bill may be too confusing to actually enforce. 

Sir William Coventry resigns his post ([8](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1666/01/08/), [9](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1666/01/09/)) and his office is split ([20](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1666/01/20/), [25](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1666/01/25/)). The Duke of York is saddened at the rather sudden death of his mistress Lady Denham ([7](http://www.pepysdiary.com/archive/1666/01/7/), [8](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1666/01/08/)) but forges on with his naval work. Under severe budget constraints, the Duke limits salary payments to only the top two Muster-Masters. Sam is happy and relieved that brother-in-law Balty is in the top slot and therefore will be paid ([16](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1666/01/16/)). Court apprehensions about the French ([2](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1666/01/02/)) continue along with gossip that in Spain, Lord Sandwich's men are involved in a deadly altercation with the French Ambassador's entourage ([29](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1666/01/29/), [30](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1666/01/30/)).

Prince Rupert becomes very ill and prepares to be trepanned ([16](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1666/01/16/), [28](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1666/01/28/), [31](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1666/01/31/)). His illness, the budget constraints, and fears of the French add to Sam's worries that "Nobody knows who commands the fleete next year, or, indeed, whether we shall have a fleete or no" ([31](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1666/01/31/)).
fields.text_html:
Sam's yearly vows, which include the usual restrictions on theatre visits (6, 7) are swiftly broken when he enjoys "The Numerous Lieutenant" (23) and is delighted to kiss the actress Nell Gwyn. Sam entertains and shows off his wonderful silver to his guests (4), although some realised that he may have acquired his flagons by dubious means (11).

Elizabeth talks to Sam's sister Pall about a potential marriage to Will Hewer, only to get a polite "thanks, but no thanks" (16, 18) . Sam gets some hard-hitting news to his wallet, when the Poll Tax Bill passes (25). Sam hopes that the complex Bill may be too confusing to actually enforce.

Sir William Coventry resigns his post (8, 9) and his office is split (20, 25). The Duke of York is saddened at the rather sudden death of his mistress Lady Denham (7, 8) but forges on with his naval work. Under severe budget constraints, the Duke limits salary payments to only the top two Muster-Masters. Sam is happy and relieved that brother-in-law Balty is in the top slot and therefore will be paid (16). Court apprehensions about the French (2) continue along with gossip that in Spain, Lord Sandwich's men are involved in a deadly altercation with the French Ambassador's entourage (29, 30).

Prince Rupert becomes very ill and prepares to be trepanned (16, 28, 31). His illness, the budget constraints, and fears of the French add to Sam's worries that "Nobody knows who commands the fleete next year, or, indeed, whether we shall have a fleete or no" (31).

fields.title: February 1667
fields.text:
Prince Rupert is trepanned and begins a slow recovery ([2](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1667/02/02/), [3](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1667/02/03/), [5](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1667/02/05/), [6](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1667/02/06/), [11](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1667/02/11/), [13](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1667/02/13/)). The loss of the St. Patrick ([6](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1667/02/06/), [17](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1667/02/17/)) adds to the Navy's fiscal stress. Sam hears that Lord Sandwich has achieved peace with Spain ([5](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1667/02/05/)) and has been ordered home to take control of the fleet ([11](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1667/02/11/), [12](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1667/02/12/)). Sam hears that peace may be possible as King Charles II enters into discussions regarding a potential Treaty with the Dutch ([14](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1667/02/14/)). While Sam enjoys his side deal with Gawden ([4](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1667/02/04/)), the Duke of York comes to understand that without any money there will be no fleet ([17](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1667/02/17/)). On an optimistic note, the plans for the rebuilding of the city get underway ([24](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1667/02/24/), [28](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1667/02/28/)).

Sam has a very musical/theatrical month ([12](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1667/02/12/), [16](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1667/02/16/), [18](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1667/02/18/)) with lots of theatre talk and entertainment. He digs deep in his pockets and buys Elizabeth a watch ([9](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1667/02/09/)) and also pays for a special splurge on Betty Mitchell ([5](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1667/02/05/)), as well as his yearly Valentine gifts ([16](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1667/02/16/), [27](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1667/02/27/)). Sam gets a shock when his brother John falls suddenly ill and is almost surprised to realise that he cares deeply for his brother ([7](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1667/02/07/), [8](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1667/02/08/)).
fields.text_html:
Prince Rupert is trepanned and begins a slow recovery (2, 3, 5, 6, 11, 13). The loss of the St. Patrick (6, 17) adds to the Navy's fiscal stress. Sam hears that Lord Sandwich has achieved peace with Spain (5) and has been ordered home to take control of the fleet (11, 12). Sam hears that peace may be possible as King Charles II enters into discussions regarding a potential Treaty with the Dutch (14). While Sam enjoys his side deal with Gawden (4), the Duke of York comes to understand that without any money there will be no fleet (17). On an optimistic note, the plans for the rebuilding of the city get underway (24, 28).

Sam has a very musical/theatrical month (12, 16, 18) with lots of theatre talk and entertainment. He digs deep in his pockets and buys Elizabeth a watch (9) and also pays for a special splurge on Betty Mitchell (5), as well as his yearly Valentine gifts (16, 27). Sam gets a shock when his brother John falls suddenly ill and is almost surprised to realise that he cares deeply for his brother (7, 8).

fields.title: March 1667
fields.text:
The King juggles the politics of the French and Dutch, which leaves the merchants in a quandary, swaying between war or peace, and uncertain whether it's best to buy or sell ([1](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1667/03/01/), [3](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1667/03/03/), [4](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1667/03/04/), [6](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1667/03/06/), [11](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1667/03/11/), [15](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1667/03/15/)). The Duke of Buckingham is accused of the treasonable act of having the King's nativity calculated and seems destined for the Tower ([3](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1667/03/03/), [6](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1667/03/06/), [9](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1667/03/09/), [11](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1667/03/11/)).  Lord Sandwich has returned to favour with the King ([17](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1667/03/17/)), while the Duke of Richmond is betrothed to the apple of the King's eye, the lovely Mrs. Stewart ([18](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1667/03/18/), [20](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1667/03/20/)). 

Sam meets a potential prospect for sister Pall ([18](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1667/03/18/)). While Sam secures a Muster-Master position for Balty on Harman's upcoming voyage to the West Indies ([27](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1667/03/27/), [29](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1667/03/29/)), he side steps taking Balty's wife into his home while Balty is away. Sam's brother John sends an alarming letter that both their mother and father are ill with Margaret close to death ([20](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1667/03/20/), [21](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1667/03/21/)). As her health declines further, Sam has a troublesome dream of his mother ([25](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1667/03/25/)) and decides to skip his yearly stone feast ([26](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1667/03/26/)) due to fears of her death. Then a letter arrives of her passing and Sam and Elizabeth weep as they read that Margaret's last words are "God bless my poor Sam".  He prepares to have the "extended family" properly suited for mourning, and when he attends church in his new periwig and mourning attire he notes that he "made a great shew" ([31](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1667/03/31/)).
fields.text_html:
The King juggles the politics of the French and Dutch, which leaves the merchants in a quandary, swaying between war or peace, and uncertain whether it's best to buy or sell (1, 3, 4, 6, 11, 15). The Duke of Buckingham is accused of the treasonable act of having the King's nativity calculated and seems destined for the Tower (3, 6, 9, 11). Lord Sandwich has returned to favour with the King (17), while the Duke of Richmond is betrothed to the apple of the King's eye, the lovely Mrs. Stewart (18, 20).

Sam meets a potential prospect for sister Pall (18). While Sam secures a Muster-Master position for Balty on Harman's upcoming voyage to the West Indies (27, 29), he side steps taking Balty's wife into his home while Balty is away. Sam's brother John sends an alarming letter that both their mother and father are ill with Margaret close to death (20, 21). As her health declines further, Sam has a troublesome dream of his mother (25) and decides to skip his yearly stone feast (26) due to fears of her death. Then a letter arrives of her passing and Sam and Elizabeth weep as they read that Margaret's last words are "God bless my poor Sam". He prepares to have the "extended family" properly suited for mourning, and when he attends church in his new periwig and mourning attire he notes that he "made a great shew" (31).

fields.title: April 1667
fields.text: Amidst anxieties over peace ([7](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1667/04/07/), [9](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1667/04/09/), [11](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1667/04/11/)) and his naval work responsibilities, Sam enjoys a week's worth of plays, only to hear the gossip that his people find him minding his pleasure too much these days ([19](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1667/04/19/)), something Sam vows to quickly correct ([20](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1667/04/20/)). Sam pays for his mother's mourning expenses ([6](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1667/04/06/)) and is relieved that his father is on the mend ([13](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1667/04/13/)). Sam gets Balty a position as Deputy Treasurer of the Fleete, which comes with a 1500l. salary, but in his wisdom, Sam puts the management of the money in Elizabeth's hands to care for her financially challenged parents ([3](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1667/04/03/), [4](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1667/04/04/)). Sam isn't so lucky in the financial area when the Collectors of the Poll money come to visit ([5](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1667/04/05/)). Sam's dear Betty Mitchell delivers a healthy baby girl ([23](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1667/04/23/), [26](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1667/04/26/)). John Evelyn defends the virtue of Frances Stewart, who recently married the Duke of Richmond ([26](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1667/04/26/)), and shares his thoughts on other Court gossip. Lord Sandwich's family, always in bad financial straits ([27](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1667/04/27/)) has some potential good news, with the hopeful return of Sandwich and the potential [10](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1667/04/10/),000l. portion for the match between Lord Hinchingbroke and Lord Burlington's daughter ([29](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1667/04/29/)).
fields.text_html:
Amidst anxieties over peace (7, 9, 11) and his naval work responsibilities, Sam enjoys a week's worth of plays, only to hear the gossip that his people find him minding his pleasure too much these days (19), something Sam vows to quickly correct (20).

Sam pays for his mother's mourning expenses (6) and is relieved that his father is on the mend (13). Sam gets Balty a position as Deputy Treasurer of the Fleete, which comes with a 1500l. salary, but in his wisdom, Sam puts the management of the money in Elizabeth's hands to care for her financially challenged parents (3, 4). Sam isn't so lucky in the financial area when the Collectors of the Poll money come to visit (5).

Sam's dear Betty Mitchell delivers a healthy baby girl (23, 26). John Evelyn defends the virtue of Frances Stewart, who recently married the Duke of Richmond (26), and shares his thoughts on other Court gossip. Lord Sandwich's family, always in bad financial straits (27) has some potential good news, with the hopeful return of Sandwich and the potential 10,000l. portion for the match between Lord Hinchingbroke and Lord Burlington's daughter (29).

fields.title: May 1667
fields.text:
Life transitions as Betty Mitchell's daughter, Elizabeth, is christened ([5](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1667/05/05/)) and the Duke of York loses one son to illness while the other struggles to stay alive ([14](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1667/05/14/), [23](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1667/05/23/), [25](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1667/05/25/), [27](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1667/05/27/)). The Lord Treasurer also passes away, leaving questions as to who will replace him ([16](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1667/05/16/)). Lord Hinchingbrooke's business of marriage to Lord Burlington's daughter is concluded with the lady very pleased to hear the news ([9](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1667/05/09/), [15](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1667/05/15/)). Sam's household also changes, with a lying Barker and a drunken Luce let go ([12](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1667/05/12/), [13](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1667/05/13/), [18](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1667/05/18/)) and two new arrivals to take their place ([21](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1667/05/21/)). 

Sam is angered at Elizabeth for her trendy white locks ([11](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1667/05/11/), [12](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1667/05/12/)) and her second mourning attire ([29](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1667/05/29/)), and they exchange words. Sam's father arrives and Sam continues to worry about his health ([14](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1667/05/14/), [22](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1667/05/22/), [23](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1667/05/23/), [26](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1667/05/26/)). 

While the Navy continues to struggle about how to pay their creditors ([6](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1667/05/06/), [8](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1667/05/08/)), Sam finds himself flush enough in his own finances to start planning to get a coach of his own and a stable to house it in ([8](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1667/05/08/), [11](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1667/05/11/), [21](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1667/05/21/)). He enjoys a great gossip session with Mrs. Turner, who dishes on the Lord Brouncker, his whore Mrs. Williams and "the most false fellow" Sir W. Pen ([21](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1667/05/21/)).
fields.text_html:
Life transitions as Betty Mitchell's daughter, Elizabeth, is christened (5) and the Duke of York loses one son to illness while the other struggles to stay alive (14, 23, 25, 27). The Lord Treasurer also passes away, leaving questions as to who will replace him (16). Lord Hinchingbrooke's business of marriage to Lord Burlington's daughter is concluded with the lady very pleased to hear the news (9, 15). Sam's household also changes, with a lying Barker and a drunken Luce let go (12, 13, 18) and two new arrivals to take their place (21).

Sam is angered at Elizabeth for her trendy white locks (11, 12) and her second mourning attire (29), and they exchange words. Sam's father arrives and Sam continues to worry about his health (14, 22, 23, 26).

While the Navy continues to struggle about how to pay their creditors (6, 8), Sam finds himself flush enough in his own finances to start planning to get a coach of his own and a stable to house it in (8, 11, 21). He enjoys a great gossip session with Mrs. Turner, who dishes on the Lord Brouncker, his whore Mrs. Williams and "the most false fellow" Sir W. Pen (21).

fields.title: June 1667
fields.text:
The Dutch begin relentless naval attacks and victories against the English ([8](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1667/06/08/), [9](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1667/06/09/), [10](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1667/06/10/), [12](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1667/06/12/), [13](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1667/06/13/), [18](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1667/06/18/), [27](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1667/06/27/)), who lack the ships and power to keep them at bay. Without any funds to pay them, and long overdue outstanding debts owed them, the seamen will not go forth to fight the Dutch and many people fear that they will defect, as they may get paid by the Dutch ([14](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1667/06/14/), [23](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1667/06/23/), [25](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1667/06/25/)). During these attacks the King sups with Lady Castlemaine ([21](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1667/06/21/)) which further ignites the fury of the people. Blame is passed out as Pett is made a scapegoat ([19](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1667/06/19/)), Sir George Carteret swaps his Treasurer of the Navy job with Lord Anglesey and takes his position of Treasurer of Ireland ([26](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1667/06/26/)). Sir William Coventry fears that he, along with the Lord Chancellor, Lord Arlington and the Vice Chamberlain are also at risk ([29](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1667/06/29/)). 

During this turmoil Sam fears for his life and his finances. He wisely sends Elizabeth and his father to the country to hide his money ([12](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1667/06/12/), [13](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1667/06/13/), [14](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1667/06/14/)), but is angry with the lack of care taken in this task ([19](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1667/06/19/), [20](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1667/06/20/)). He makes his will, splitting his belongings equally between his father and Elizabeth ([13](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1667/06/13/)). Sam turns down Lord Sandwich's request for a loan ([17](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1667/06/17/)); with the banks in such disarray, he wants to protect his belongings. 

There are two very sad, young losses this month with the death of Betty Mitchell's new daughter, Elizabeth ([11](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1667/06/11/), [15](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1667/06/15/), [18](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1667/06/18/)) and the Duke of York's son, the Duke of Cambridge ([6](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1667/06/06/), [9](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1667/06/09/), [22](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1667/06/22/)).
fields.text_html:
The Dutch begin relentless naval attacks and victories against the English (8, 9, 10, 12, 13, 18, 27), who lack the ships and power to keep them at bay. Without any funds to pay them, and long overdue outstanding debts owed them, the seamen will not go forth to fight the Dutch and many people fear that they will defect, as they may get paid by the Dutch (14, 23, 25). During these attacks the King sups with Lady Castlemaine (21) which further ignites the fury of the people. Blame is passed out as Pett is made a scapegoat (19), Sir George Carteret swaps his Treasurer of the Navy job with Lord Anglesey and takes his position of Treasurer of Ireland (26). Sir William Coventry fears that he, along with the Lord Chancellor, Lord Arlington and the Vice Chamberlain are also at risk (29).

During this turmoil Sam fears for his life and his finances. He wisely sends Elizabeth and his father to the country to hide his money (12, 13, 14), but is angry with the lack of care taken in this task (19, 20). He makes his will, splitting his belongings equally between his father and Elizabeth (13). Sam turns down Lord Sandwich's request for a loan (17); with the banks in such disarray, he wants to protect his belongings.

There are two very sad, young losses this month with the death of Betty Mitchell's new daughter, Elizabeth (11, 15, 18) and the Duke of York's son, the Duke of Cambridge (6, 9, 22).

fields.title: July 1667
fields.text: The Dutch attacks and political fallout continue, with the people turning against the management of the Navy. As many shift in and out of favor, Sam is the "only happy man of the Navy" as not one bad word has been spoken about him ([2](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1667/07/02/), [3](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1667/07/03/), [12](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1667/07/12/)). While Lady Castlemaine and the King argue about the paternity of the child she is carrying ([27](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1667/07/27/), [29](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1667/07/29/)), stories of the King's lingering love for Frances Stewart continue ([17](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1667/07/17/)), and court factions are ongoing ([27](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1667/07/27/)). Sir George Carteret passes the Seal to Lord Anglesey. Sam resigns his victualling position ([29](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1667/07/29/)), and loses the 300l. a year that goes with it. Peace finally is confirmed, leaving the people upset as they wonder what price their lackluster and highly disrespected King, has paid for it ([11](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1667/07/11/), [12](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1667/07/12/), [13](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1667/07/13/), [19](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1667/07/19/), [29](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1667/07/29/)). Betty Mitchell tells Sam she is pregnant and he fears it is his child ([3](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1667/07/03/)). Three days later, when Betty finds she is not with child, Sam celebrates by buying wine for all ([6](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1667/07/06/)). Later in the month he sprains his ankle and is in pain for several days ([14](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1667/07/14/), [15](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1667/07/15/), [16](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1667/07/16/), [17](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1667/07/17/)). On a happy note, Lady Jemimah gives birth to a son ([6](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1667/07/06/)).
fields.text_html:
The Dutch attacks and political fallout continue, with the people turning against the management of the Navy. As many shift in and out of favor, Sam is the "only happy man of the Navy" as not one bad word has been spoken about him (2, 3, 12). While Lady Castlemaine and the King argue about the paternity of the child she is carrying (27, 29), stories of the King's lingering love for Frances Stewart continue (17), and court factions are ongoing (27). Sir George Carteret passes the Seal to Lord Anglesey. Sam resigns his victualling position (29), and loses the 300l. a year that goes with it. Peace finally is confirmed, leaving the people upset as they wonder what price their lackluster and highly disrespected King, has paid for it (11, 12, 13, 19, 29).

Betty Mitchell tells Sam she is pregnant and he fears it is his child (3). Three days later, when Betty finds she is not with child, Sam celebrates by buying wine for all (6). Later in the month he sprains his ankle and is in pain for several days (14, 15, 16, 17). On a happy note, Lady Jemimah gives birth to a son (6).

fields.title: August 1667
fields.text:
Sam nervously waits for an official peace announcement and, like many, expresses his concern that he's not sure if he is glad or sorry about the peace; although it's necessary, the terms for it are not favorable ([14](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1667/08/14/), [16](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1667/08/16/), [19](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1667/08/19/), [22](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1667/08/22/), [24](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1667/08/24/)). Sam continues his work on the large general accounts of expenses and debts of the Navy ([4](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1667/08/04/)). Amid a growing anxiety over the economic instability, John Evelyn and Mr. Burges share a common concern that many are collecting their money either to have it in hand, or to get it out of the country and into safe keeping ([8](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1667/08/08/), [9](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1667/08/09/)). 

Mid-month Sam returns to seeing plays with a wild vengeance, racking up about thirteen this month. He declares that his belly is "full with plays, that I do intend to bind myself to see no
more till Michaelmas" ([24](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1667/08/24/)), yet he's back to the theatre [2](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1667/08/02/) days later. Elizabeth has had her fill of Sam's theatre antics with her well justified jealousy of his relationship with Mrs. Knipp ([2](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1667/08/02/)). 

The political fallout continues and divides many. The King goes after the seal of Lord Clarendon (father-in-law to the Duke of York, who supports him). By month end the King prevails and the Chancellor is sadly out of his position.
fields.text_html:
Sam nervously waits for an official peace announcement and, like many, expresses his concern that he's not sure if he is glad or sorry about the peace; although it's necessary, the terms for it are not favorable (14, 16, 19, 22, 24). Sam continues his work on the large general accounts of expenses and debts of the Navy (4). Amid a growing anxiety over the economic instability, John Evelyn and Mr. Burges share a common concern that many are collecting their money either to have it in hand, or to get it out of the country and into safe keeping (8, 9).

Mid-month Sam returns to seeing plays with a wild vengeance, racking up about thirteen this month. He declares that his belly is "full with plays, that I do intend to bind myself to see no more till Michaelmas" (24), yet he's back to the theatre 2 days later. Elizabeth has had her fill of Sam's theatre antics with her well justified jealousy of his relationship with Mrs. Knipp (2).

The political fallout continues and divides many. The King goes after the seal of Lord Clarendon (father-in-law to the Duke of York, who supports him). By month end the King prevails and the Chancellor is sadly out of his position.

fields.title: September 1667
fields.text:
Political fallout continues with the departure of the Chancellor ([2](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1667/09/02/)). Sir Coventry leaves the Duke of York's service and is replaced by Mr. Wren ([2](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1667/09/02/), [4](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1667/09/04/), [8](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1667/09/08/)) but Sam is upset to lose a man that he admired and sadly starts the transition period to Mr. Wren ([10](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1667/09/10/), [17](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1667/09/17/)).

Sam continues to sort through gossip versus facts this month. Truths include an Act of Council which called for the removal of all Papists from their offices ([8](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1667/09/08/)), and peace with Spain ([27](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1667/09/27/)). False rumours include the King setting Monmouth up for the Crown ([14](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1667/09/14/)), Lady Castlemaine departing to Paris ([5](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1667/09/05/)), and the barren Queen being sent to a nunnery ([5](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1667/09/05/), [16](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1667/09/16/)). Good news befalls the Duke of York as his wife gives birth to a son, Edgar ([14](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1667/09/14/)). 

Sam's eyes cause him a great pain and he relies on his family to read to him ([22](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1667/09/22/)). He is pleased by Elizabeth's talents on the flageolet ([11](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1667/09/11/), [12](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1667/09/12/)) and disguises his pleasure at the arrival of Elizabeth's new companion, the pretty Deb Willet ([27](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1667/09/27/), [30](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1667/09/30/)).
fields.text_html:
Political fallout continues with the departure of the Chancellor (2). Sir Coventry leaves the Duke of York's service and is replaced by Mr. Wren (2, 4, 8) but Sam is upset to lose a man that he admired and sadly starts the transition period to Mr. Wren (10, 17).

Sam continues to sort through gossip versus facts this month. Truths include an Act of Council which called for the removal of all Papists from their offices (8), and peace with Spain (27). False rumours include the King setting Monmouth up for the Crown (14), Lady Castlemaine departing to Paris (5), and the barren Queen being sent to a nunnery (5, 16). Good news befalls the Duke of York as his wife gives birth to a son, Edgar (14).

Sam's eyes cause him a great pain and he relies on his family to read to him (22). He is pleased by Elizabeth's talents on the flageolet (11, 12) and disguises his pleasure at the arrival of Elizabeth's new companion, the pretty Deb Willet (27, 30).

fields.title: October 1667
fields.text:
Sir W. Batten falls ill which trouble Sam "partly out of kindness, he being a good neighbour and partly because of the money he owes me, upon our bargain of the late prize" ([3](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1667/10/03/), [4](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1667/10/04/)). The next day, Batten is dead. 

Sam doesn't stay around for the funeral but gathers up the ladies and heads off to Brampton to collect the gold that his father buried last June ([7](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1667/10/07/), [8](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1667/10/08/), [9](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1667/10/09/)). He visits "my Lady" to hear the news of her family and discusses his family concerns with his father ([9](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1667/10/09/), [10](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1667/10/10/)). He begins the "great work to dig up my gold" which turns out to be a near nightmare ([10](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1667/10/10/), [11](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1667/10/11/)). Sam returns home with the gold and hears the news that Parliament has met. 

Sam is pulled into several different examinations into the war. A committee to look into the miscarriages into the conduct of the entire war is created ([17](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1667/10/17/)) and Sam finds himself losing sleep over the headaches of the payment of seamen via tickets.
fields.text_html:
Sir W. Batten falls ill which trouble Sam "partly out of kindness, he being a good neighbour and partly because of the money he owes me, upon our bargain of the late prize" (3, 4). The next day, Batten is dead.

Sam doesn't stay around for the funeral but gathers up the ladies and heads off to Brampton to collect the gold that his father buried last June (7, 8, 9). He visits "my Lady" to hear the news of her family and discusses his family concerns with his father (9, 10). He begins the "great work to dig up my gold" which turns out to be a near nightmare (10, 11). Sam returns home with the gold and hears the news that Parliament has met.

Sam is pulled into several different examinations into the war. A committee to look into the miscarriages into the conduct of the entire war is created (17) and Sam finds himself losing sleep over the headaches of the payment of seamen via tickets.

fields.title: November 1667
fields.text:
Political pundits, Parliament, and the Committees reviewing war-related issues "attack" the Naval Office and Sam's goal is to keep himself clean during the turmoil. Sir W. Coventry's conduct is criticized by the Narratives of the Duke of Albemarle and Prince Rupert ([1](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1667/11/01/), [4](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1667/11/04/)) and Sam fears what may befall Lord Sandwich ([1](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1667/11/01/), [3](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1667/11/03/), [6](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1667/11/06/), [13](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1667/11/13/)). The King's political pals work to impeach the Lord Chancellor ([4](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1667/11/04/), [9](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1667/11/09/), [12](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1667/11/12/), [15](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1667/11/15/), [21](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1667/11/21/)). 

Roger Pepys tips Sam off that "the Committee is mighty full of the business of buying and selling of tickets", but believes that they have found someone else to blame, so Sam may be safe ([13](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1667/11/13/)). Prince Rupert's people, who are investigating the prize-good related activities, pull Poundy, the waterman, to bear witness against Sam ([15](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1667/11/15/)). Sam receives an order to bring all the books to the Committee lead by Brookes ([19](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1667/11/19/)), but he is careful to review them before he delivers them ([20](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1667/11/20/)), so that he can prepare his defense ([24](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1667/11/24/)).  

Sam's eyes continue to bother him and he visits the spectacle-maker ([4](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1667/11/04/)). Sam replies to a letter from his father letter detailing what he will provide to a new potential husband for Pall ([19](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1667/11/19/)). Sam once again vows to cut back on his play going ([13](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1667/11/13/)), and a noise in the night reads like a comedy as Sam and his "extended family" fear that a thief is afoot ([29](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1667/11/29/)).
fields.text_html:
Political pundits, Parliament, and the Committees reviewing war-related issues "attack" the Naval Office and Sam's goal is to keep himself clean during the turmoil. Sir W. Coventry's conduct is criticized by the Narratives of the Duke of Albemarle and Prince Rupert (1, 4) and Sam fears what may befall Lord Sandwich (1, 3, 6, 13). The King's political pals work to impeach the Lord Chancellor (4, 9, 12, 15, 21).

Roger Pepys tips Sam off that "the Committee is mighty full of the business of buying and selling of tickets", but believes that they have found someone else to blame, so Sam may be safe (13). Prince Rupert's people, who are investigating the prize-good related activities, pull Poundy, the waterman, to bear witness against Sam (15). Sam receives an order to bring all the books to the Committee lead by Brookes (19), but he is careful to review them before he delivers them (20), so that he can prepare his defense (24).

Sam's eyes continue to bother him and he visits the spectacle-maker (4). Sam replies to a letter from his father letter detailing what he will provide to a new potential husband for Pall (19). Sam once again vows to cut back on his play going (13), and a noise in the night reads like a comedy as Sam and his "extended family" fear that a thief is afoot (29).

fields.title: December 1667
fields.text:
As Parliament continues to argue about what charges to bring against the Lord Chancellor ([2](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1667/12/02/)), the wise Chancellor escapes ([3](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1667/12/03/)). In retaliation, the Lords move to formally banish him ([13](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1667/12/13/)). Sam is nervous as the committees established to look into the finances and administrations of the war have no members that understand the working of a naval operation ([8](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1667/12/08/)). Sir W. Coventry, in his wisdom, cautions Sam that when he goes before Parliament he should "say little, and let them get out what they can by force" ([3](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1667/12/03/)). 

Sam begrudgingly helps out with Lord Sandwich's bill of exchange ([13](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1667/12/13/), [18](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1667/12/18/)). Sam discusses Pall's proposed match ([21](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1667/12/21/)) with his wife Elizabeth who has endured a swollen face and horrible tooth ache for several days ([21](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1667/12/21/), [22](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1667/12/22/), [23](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1667/12/23/)). Christmas Day is spent quietly at home. Sam ends the year with his usual worries for the nation and his more personal worries of where he will end up standing in his Office when the Committee of Parliament examines the Navy matters ([31](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1667/12/31/)).
fields.text_html:
As Parliament continues to argue about what charges to bring against the Lord Chancellor (2), the wise Chancellor escapes (3). In retaliation, the Lords move to formally banish him (13). Sam is nervous as the committees established to look into the finances and administrations of the war have no members that understand the working of a naval operation (8). Sir W. Coventry, in his wisdom, cautions Sam that when he goes before Parliament he should "say little, and let them get out what they can by force" (3).

Sam begrudgingly helps out with Lord Sandwich's bill of exchange (13, 18). Sam discusses Pall's proposed match (21) with his wife Elizabeth who has endured a swollen face and horrible tooth ache for several days (21, 22, 23). Christmas Day is spent quietly at home. Sam ends the year with his usual worries for the nation and his more personal worries of where he will end up standing in his Office when the Committee of Parliament examines the Navy matters (31).

fields.title: January 1668
fields.text: Sam works on his Tangier Accounts ([13](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1668/01/13/), [20](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1668/01/20/), [27](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1668/01/27/)) and his letter to the Commissioners of Acts, who call him before their Committee ([27](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1668/01/27/), [28](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1668/01/28/), [31](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1668/01/31/)). Regarding the Chatham business, Sam hears he made "great ground in the Parliament" and that they will "never let me be out of employment" ([5](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1668/01/05/)). While the Parliament takes things seriously, the King with his assorted actress mistresses ([14](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1668/01/14/)), and the Duke of Buckingham with his infamous Lord Shrewsbury duel, leave Sam disgusted. "This will make the world think that the King hath good councilors about him, when the Duke of Buckingham, the greatest man about him, is a fellow of no more sobriety than to fight about a whore" ([17](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1668/01/17/)). Sam is at odds with Elizabeth when Will Hewer gives her a 40l. diamond locket, which Sam tells her she can not accept. Sam concludes that Pall will marry Jackson ([10](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1668/01/10/), [11](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1668/01/11/)), but when Sam suggests that his father comes to live with them after they wed, Elizabeth and Sam have a heated argument ([12](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1668/01/12/)). Lord Hinchingbrooke is finally married, leaving Sam snubbed that he did not have a favour sent to him ([17](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1668/01/17/)). On a sad family note, Anthony Joyce attempts suicide and dies shortly thereafter, leaving Kate Joyce and family at risk of losing their home to the Crown. Sam gets the approval of the King that the house will pass to the widow and children, but by month end this is still in flux ([21](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1668/01/21/), [22](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1668/01/22/), [24](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1668/01/24/), [30](http://www.pepysdiary.com/diary/1668/01/30/)).
fields.text_html:
Sam works on his Tangier Accounts (13, 20, 27) and his letter to the Commissioners of Acts, who call him before their Committee (27, 28, 31). Regarding the Chatham business, Sam hears he made "great ground in the Parliament" and that they will "never let me be out of employment" (5). While the Parliament takes things seriously, the King with his assorted actress mistresses (14), and the Duke of Buckingham with his infamous Lord Shrewsbury duel, leave Sam disgusted. "This will make the world think that the King hath good councilors about him, when the Duke of Buckingham, the greatest man about him, is a fellow of no more sobriety than to fight about a whore" (17).

Sam is at odds with Elizabeth when Will Hewer gives her a 40l. diamond locket, which Sam tells her she can not accept. Sam concludes that Pall will marry Jackson (10, 11), but when Sam suggests that his father comes to live with them after they wed, Elizabeth and Sam have a heated argument (12). Lord Hinchingbrooke is finally married, leaving Sam snubbed that he did not have a favour sent to him (17). On a sad family note, Anthony Joyce attempts suicide and dies shortly thereafter, leaving Kate Joyce and family at risk of losing their home to the Crown. Sam gets the approval of the King that the house will pass to the widow and children, but by month end this is still in flux (21, 22, 24, 30).

fields.title: February 1668
fields.text:
